guardian_articles.headline: Sixties line-up gives Glastonbury old-fashioned feel

nytimes_articles.headline: Elizabeth Scherl and Peter Shaerf
nytimes_articles.abstract: Elizabeth Scherl, a partner in the law firm of Anderson Kill Olick & Oshinsky, and Peter Shaerf, president of Commonwealth Shipping Ltd., a ship brokerage, both in New York, were married yesterday. Rabbi Amy Erlich officiated at the Lotos Club in New York.   The bride, 37, is the daughter of S. Dorothy Scherl of Cincinnati and the late Ely Scherl. She graduated from Northwestern University, received a medical degree from the University of Cincinnati and a law degree from the University of Pennsylvania.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ali Headgear Sold At Boxer Benefit
nytimes_articles.abstract: Headgear that Muhammad Ali wore in training and later signed brought $5,500 yesterday in a fund-raising auction for Sergei Artemiev at the Trump Taj Mahal. The Russian-born lightweight contender underwent emergency brain surgery to remove a blood clot following a March 21 bout at the Taj Mahal.   Nearly $20,000 was raised toward the Brooklyn resident's medical bills.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hair Yesterday, Now She's Gone
nytimes_articles.abstract: The following letter was said to have fallen from the bag of defending champion Andre Agassi after his third-round match at the Wimbledon tennis championships. Its authenticity has not been confirmed. Therefore, we have decided to run it in its entirety.

nytimes_articles.headline: More Notable Alumni of a Brooklyn School
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   I am honored to be counted among the noted alumni of James Madison High School, alma mater of Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg, President Clinton's Supreme Court nominee (news article, June 16), but there are, in my judgment, many others perhaps more deserving. I think, for example, of Dr. Samuel Thier, president of Brandeis University, and Representative Bernard Sanders of Vermont.

nytimes_articles.headline: If It's Not Another 'Africa,' Please Not a 'Havana'
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sydney Pollack is nervous.   Although he's one of Hollywood's foremost film makers and has a remarkably successful track record as director of movies like "They Shoot Horses, Don't They?" "Tootsie" and "Out of Africa," Mr. Pollack acknowledges that the failure of his last film, "Havana," several years ago left him reeling and scared. Now he anxiously awaits the reaction to his newest movie, "The Firm," which opens on Wednesday, one day before his 60th birthday.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tigers Claw Way Back to Contention
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Detroit Tigers, never to be confused with the Atlanta Braves, knew going into spring training that the club needed pitching. Desperately.   Still, when Sparky Anderson heard that David Wells, a left-handed reliever of some note, had been released by the Toronto Blue Jays, the manager was suspicious.

nytimes_articles.headline: More Notable Alumni of a Brooklyn School
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Your June 16 article on James Madison High School notwithstanding, Sylvia Fine Kaye never graduated from Madison. She and her husband, Danny, were products of Thomas Jefferson, the Brownsville-East New York high school. Sylvia graduated in 1929, Danny in 1930 -- long before Madison's foundations were laid. I was there. I have Sylvia's picture in my class yearbook.

nytimes_articles.headline: Woman and Child Found Slain in Bronx
nytimes_articles.abstract: The bodies of a young woman and a girl were found in a Bronx apartment yesterday afternoon, the police said. They appeared to have been dead for several days, the authorities said.   A second child, a girl about 2 years old, was also found in the apartment, unharmed. She was taken to Lincoln Hospital, the police said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rushing to Gather Up Cash On Northwest's Forest Floor
nytimes_articles.abstract: The high meadows of the Blue Mountains are full of wild strawberries this month, and the bear grass sprouts smell especially sweet. But these sublimities are mere background to a rush of people crawling along the forest floor in search of mushrooms, the latest and, pound for pound, perhaps most lucrative cash crop to come out of the national forests.   Using pocket knives as their only tools, the pickers are stuffing bags with morels, chanterelles, boletus and the gold nugget of wild mushrooms, matsutakes, which sell for up to $70 a pound in Asian retail markets.

nytimes_articles.headline: Deficit Taking Toll on Lawmakers' Dreams of Big-Science Projects
nytimes_articles.abstract: It took more than strutting astronauts and brilliant astrophysicists to spawn the miracles of moon walking, microchips and satellite communications. Congress wrote the checks.   But now the ink is running out.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1943: British Air Raid : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: LONDON - [From our New York edition:] British bomber fleets roared over Hitler's European fortress for the eighth consecutive night last night [June 27] to batter targets in west and north-west Germany, carrying the mightiest nonstop aerial offensive of t

nytimes_articles.headline: Jennifer LeBrane David A. Stewart
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jennifer LeBrane, a daughter of Bettye D. LeBrane and Ruffin LeBrane, both of Seattle, was married yesterday to David A. Stewart, the son of Mr. and Mrs. St. Clair Stewart of Toronto. The Rev. Nathaniel Hollis, a Seventh Day Adventist pastor, performed the ceremony at the Gilbert Lambuth Chapel on the campus of Paine College in Augusta, Ga.   Mrs. Stewart, 24, is a registered nurse with the nursing program at the Medical College of Georgia in Augusta, from which she is a magna cum laude graduate. She graduated cum laude from Spelman College. Her father is a mental health consultant in Seattle. Her mother is a psychiatric nurse at the Seattle Mental Health Center.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article on Wednesday about a protest by police officers over the perjury conviction of an officer in New York City's 34th Precinct misidentified a neighborhood in the precinct in some editions. It is Washington Heights.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: "In the end, we won the cold war, and if we won by too much, if it was overkill, so be it." -- CASPAR W. WEINBERGER, former Secretary of Defense.  [ A10:1. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: Food Store's Low Road To the Top of the Line
nytimes_articles.abstract: As a law student, Andrew Arons began a wildly successful specialty food importing business, Flying Foods. He may or may not have introduced radicchio to the American table, as he claims, but by the time he he sold the company to Kraft Foods in 1987 for $8 million there was no denying his knowledge of the most arcane aspects of the food business.    That sale gave him money and time to figure out his next gambit in the gourmet game, and he began a long intellectual prowl. He believes he saw the light in an aisle in a Wal-Mart, though it might have been Kmart. The lesson was that odd-colored baby vegetables and the other goods he knew best could be turned over rapidly when sold at a low margin in a no-frills environment.

nytimes_articles.headline: Patti Friedman And Mark Renton
nytimes_articles.abstract: Patti Friedman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. Friedman of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Mark Renton, a son of Michael P. Renton of London and Yvonne Davis of Manchester, England. Rabbi Arnold B. Marans officiated at the St. Regis in New York.   Mrs. Renton graduated from the University of Pennsylvania. She was until recently an advertising director of L.A. Style magazine, the former magazine in New York. Her father, the retired chairman, director and founder of the Amrep Corporation, a real-estate development company in New York, is now a consultant to the company.

nytimes_articles.headline: O'Neal's Wish List Has Webber at Top
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Orlando Magic, who have Ping-Pong balls ready for their trophy case instead of trophies, are queued up first for Wednesday's college draft. Their prize of a year ago, Shaquille O'Neal, has advised them to select Michigan power forward Chris Webber, and although Magic General Manager Pat Williams's response was a lukewarm "Shaq's not G.M., not at last check," they likely will follow that course and select Webber.   An alternative, of course, is Brigham Young University's Shawn Bradley, the 7-foot-6-inch missionary who as a child strengthened his grip milking a cow named Olive.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Rural Jails, Haitians Suffer From Isolation
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the middle of an isolated Louisiana parish, 18 dejected Haitian refugees sit in two dank, windowless jail cells, a thousand miles from the company of their countrymen at a detention center in Florida, which Federal authorities say is too crowded to house them.   Looking back on the uncertain charms of nearly six months in a rural Louisiana jail -- watery grits and overcooked rice as part of typical prison fare, metal bunks with thin pallets, and, for seven female refugees in the parish's jail for women, unwelcome sexual advances from local inmates -- several Haitians yearned in recent interviews for the Krome Avenue Detention Immigration Facility in Miami, even though Haitians there have complained of beatings and harassment. One even wants to go home.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pamela Reeves, Jeffrey Goldberg
nytimes_articles.abstract: Pamela Ress Reeves, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William E. Reeves of Providence, R.I., was married there yesterday to Jeffrey Mark Goldberg, a son of Ellen H. Goldberg of Malverne, L.I., and Daniel Goldberg of Baldwin, L.I. Rabbi Wayne Franklin performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El.

nytimes_articles.headline: Star of Cozzene Beats (Ties) Lure
nytimes_articles.abstract: American racing needs two things, people have been saying: stars and a story line. And it got both yesterday when Star of Cozzene ran down Lure in the homestretch to win the $500,000 Caesar's International at the Atlantic City Race Course and tie their sizzling rivalry at two victories apiece.   The two speed horses, the best on grass and maybe the best on any surface, renewed their competition just half an hour after the colt Great Navigator joined the growing casualty list of thoroughbreds when he suffered a broken ankle bone during the Jersey Shore Breeders' Cup. The accident was said by the track's veterinarians to be career threatening but probably not life threatening, and the horse was taken to the hospital with a splint and brace on his left foreleg.

nytimes_articles.headline: Despite Change, Reform Is Slow In the Teamsters
nytimes_articles.abstract: When Ron Carey became president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters last year, he was regarded as the living representation of reform. After decades of control by organized crime at the teamsters, it was goodbye to corruption, Mr. Carey vowed.   But Federal investigators say Mr. Carey has yet to meet the high standard he set for himself as the first democratically elected head of the 1.4 million-member union.

nytimes_articles.headline: At Home Abroad; Time to Change
nytimes_articles.abstract: When hundreds of right-wing whites the other day smashed into the hall where South Africa's future is being negotiated, they achieved a paradoxical result. They made clear how urgently necessary it is to conclude the talks and move toward a democratic government that has the legitimacy to govern.   A new South Africa has been trying to emerge for more than three years now. But there was the old, unchanged: a gun-toting white mob hardly challenged by the police, who would surely have used at least tear gas and probably weapons against a black protest half as violent.

nytimes_articles.headline: Maia Gahtan and Leif W. Haase
nytimes_articles.abstract: Maia Gahtan, the daughter of Roben and Evelyn Gahtan of Berkeley, Calif., was married yesterday in Weston, Conn., to Leif Wellington Haase, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin R. Haase of Chester, Nova Scotia. The Rev. James Avery, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the Cobb's Mill Inn.   The bride, 27, and her husband, 28, are doctoral candidates at Yale University, she in Renaissance studies and he in American studies. She graduated summa cum laude from Yale and received a master's degree in art history from the University of Chicago. Her father, who is retired, was an architect in San Francisco. Her mother is a senior reference librarian at the Berkeley Public Library.

nytimes_articles.headline: Marc W. Greene and Ellen Jane Field
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ellen Jane Field, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest R. Field of Kings Point, L.I., was married yesterday to Marc William Greene, the son of Suzanne Greene of Brookville, L.I., and the late Dr. Robert Greene. Rabbi Jerome Davidson performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.   Mrs. Greene, 28, is an associate at the Wadsworth Company, an investment banking concern in New York. She graduated from Colby College and received an M.B.A. from New York University. Her father and her mother, Marcia K. Field, are principals of Field & Field, a law firm in Manhasset, L.I.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dance in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: 'Cement Garden' 'Experiments and Developments in Dance'   Rebecca Ashley  The Studio  145 West 46th Street  Manhattan    Rebecca Ashley's dances were both laudably ambitious and dismayingly vague on Saturday night, when she presented a program under the auspices of the Next Stage Company, a theatrical organization directed by Gus Reyes.

nytimes_articles.headline: Quotations That Win or Lose Elections
nytimes_articles.abstract: NO ONE knows for sure at what moment Abraham D. Beame lost the 1977 mayoral race, but the night he appeared on "We, the Jury" is as good a guess as any.   Mr. Beame, who had been elected four years earlier on the slogan, "He Knows the Buck," spent much of the program on the defensive, seeking to acquit himself of criticism, just leveled by the Securities and Exchange Commission, that he had misled New Yorkers about city finances. Mr. Beame insisted, instead, that only because of his stewardship had bankruptcy been averted.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dance in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Extended Dance Company   Theater of the Riverside Church    Last winter, the Extended Dance Company made a favorable impression with a choreographically fresh program that emphasized jazz-dance technique. Jazz dance was again featured on Thursday night when the group appeared at the Theater of the Riverside Church. And Val Suarez's "Wave," one of the notable productions of that earlier program, was as stormy as ever.

nytimes_articles.headline: Can't Tell the Teams Without a Program
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Grand Alee is the main drag in this old French town. On Saturday night, its broad roadway was filled with slowly cruising cars, its sidewalks were surging with tourists and most of the outdoor cafes' tables were packed with members of the hockey mob.   Executives, players, reporters and fans had escaped the sweltering Colisee after the National Hockey League's daylong entry draft that ended the league's annual convention that signals the end of one long season and the approach of the next.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cliffhanger: Can Early Movies Be Saved in Time?
nytimes_articles.abstract: The art of the cinema may be forever, but the film stock is not. A four-volume report released late last week by the Library of Congress offers, for the first time, a comprehensive survey of film preservation in the United States by film studios, archives and individuals.    Entitled "Film Preservation 1993: A Study of the Current State of American Film Preservation," the report describes a losing battle against time, with inadequately financed preservationists racing to fend off the threat posed by deterioration of film stock and to reconstruct the original versions of films that have been altered over time.

nytimes_articles.headline: RAID ON BAGHDAD: The United Nations; U.S. Presents Evidence to U.N. Justifying Its Missile Attack on Iraq
nytimes_articles.abstract: Showing pictures of bomb components, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations presented detailed evidence today to support the Clinton Administration's case that it was legally justified in carrying out a missile attack on an Iraqi intelligence site in Baghdad.   The delegate, Madeleine K. Albright,said United States retaliation was consistent with Article 51 of the United Nations Charter, which provides for the right of self-defense, for what American officials have concluded was a plot by the Iraqi Government to assassinate former President George Bush in Kuwait.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tatiana Dimitriades, Jonathan Bass
nytimes_articles.abstract: Tatiana Anastasia Dimitriades, a violinist with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, was married yesterday to Jonathan David Bass, a concert pianist in San Jose, Calif. The Rev. David Cockcroft, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Estherwood, in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel took part in the ceremony.   Ms. Dimitriades is keeping her name. She graduated from Indiana University, from which she also received a master's degree in music. She is a daughter of Ruth and Peter Dimitriades of New York. The bride's father is a concert violinist. Her mother, known professionally as Ruth Lansche, was a soprano in the chorus of the Metropolitan Opera and is now a voice teacher at the Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, Conn.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Forests and the Fees
nytimes_articles.abstract:
In an effort to pressure Congress to increase the National Park Service budget, the Wilderness Society has distributed a list of cutbacks Americans are likely to encounter at their favorite parks this summer.

Though Congress appropriated more than $1 billion for fiscal 1993, the National Park Service says it is not enough to maintain services at 1992 levels. So, Yosemite is closing two campgrounds, Cape Hatteras National Seashore is reducing lifeguard service and Shenandoah National Park delayed opening a campground by three months.

nytimes_articles.headline: Romina Field And Oded Weiss
nytimes_articles.abstract: Romina Field, the daughter of Carl and Pearl Field of Briarwood, Queens, was married yesterday to Oded Weiss, a son of Dina Weiss of Ramat Hasharon, Israel, and the late Yigal Weiss. Rabbi Moshe Turk performed the ceremony at the Pierre in New York.   The bride, 25, is an associate at Roberts & Holland, a New York law firm. She graduated summa cum laude from Columbia University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She received a law degree from Harvard University.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dance in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nanette Bearden Contemporary Dance Theater  Marymount Manhattan Theater    There were some fine solo performances in the varied program that the Nanette Bearden Contemporary Dance Theater presented on Friday night.

nytimes_articles.headline: More Notable Alumni of a Brooklyn School
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Your June 16 article on the distinguished graduates of James Madison High in Brooklyn fails to mention the writer Irwin Shaw, author of the novels "The Young Lions" and "Rich Man, Poor Man," and of such short stories as "The 80-Yard Run" and "The Girls in Their Summer Dresses." Irwin Shaw attended James Madison from 1925 to 1929, graduating just before his 16th birthday.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mr. Stein's Spending, Then and Now
nytimes_articles.abstract: The city's Campaign Finance Board will soon rule on a provocative question about Council President Andrew Stein's campaign for re-election. In his unofficial campaign for mayor, Mr. Stein raised and spent about $2.7 million. Then he decided to run for re-election to his old job instead. Should his spending be credited to his new campaign or to his failed one?   Sounds like a technicality, but the impact of the board's decision will be anything but technical. Mr. Stein's opponents are participating in the city's system of public campaign financing; he is not. He raised his millions without conforming to the strict spending and contribution limits in the city's law. Now Mr. Stein says he will voluntarily abide by those limits, although it's too late for him to participate in the program itself.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bridge
nytimes_articles.abstract: Two of the four teams to represent the United States in Chile in September have been decided here, but the others are still up for grabs.   Michael Becker of Tenafly, N.J., Ron Rubin of North Miami Beach, Fla., Bob Levin of Hallandale, Fla., Peter Weichsel of Encenitas, Calif., Ron Sukoneck of Annandale, Va., and Russ Ekeblad of Providence, R.I., won comfortably on Saturday by 62 imps against Neil Chambers of Schenectady, N.Y., John Schermer of Seattle, Roger Bates of Mesa, Ariz., John Mohan of Santa Monica, Calif., Michael Passell of Dallas and Andy Goodman of San Francisco.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1918: Ex-Tsar Killed?: IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: PARIS - Although confirmation is still lacking of the assassination of the ex-Tsar of Russia, there are strong indications that the report is founded. A Kiev despatch and several telegrams received yesterday [June 27] give the news from various sources, m

nytimes_articles.headline: Leslie Moskowitz, David Elfenbein
nytimes_articles.abstract: Leslie Brett Moskowitz and David Henry Elfenbein, third-year medical students at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx, were married yesterday. Rabbi Arnold Turetsky performed the ceremony at Congregation Kneses Tifereth Israel in Port Chester, N.Y.   Mrs. Elfenbein, 23, graduated magna cum laude from Brandeis University. She is a daughter of Harold and Helyn Moskowitz of Huntington Beach, Calif. Her father, now retired, was an accountant in Hawthorne, Calif., for the Northrop Corporation, the aerospace company.

nytimes_articles.headline: Blacks Rejecting Gay Rights As a Battle Equal to Theirs
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ronald Prince has lived a gay life since his mid-teens. Now 43, he readily recalls moments when he hid his homosexuality rather than face public ridicule.   "In high school, when students would poke fun at 'faggots' or 'sissies,' I wouldn't speak up," he said. "I'd go along with the crowd." The facade he kept up included disguising what he considered potentially effeminate mannerisms.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bring Russia and Ukraine Into NATO Together; Economic, Not Ethnic
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Ukraine Lawmakers Balk at Anti-Crisis Plan" (news article, June 16) calls Ukraine's Donbas, where an explosion of strikes has occurred, a region where a majority of the population is ethnically Russian.

nytimes_articles.headline: Diane A. Cohen and Edward Koones
nytimes_articles.abstract: Diane Alice Cohen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Cohen of Livingston, N.J., was married yesterday to Edward Koones, the son of Seymour Koones of Brooklyn and the late Geraldine Koones. Rabbi Azriel C. Fellner officiated at the Metropolitan Club in New York.   Mrs. Koones is a securities trader at Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities in New York. She graduated from New York University, from which she received an M.B.A.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sharon Klein, Elliott Dobin
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sharon Klein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Klein of Roslyn Heights, L.I., was married yesterday to Elliott Scott Dobin, the son of Mrs. Jack Dobin of New York and the late Mr. Dobin. Rabbi Miriam Ancis performed the ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

nytimes_articles.headline: RAID ON BAGHDAD: Reaction; European Allies Are Giving Strong Backing to U.S. Raid
nytimes_articles.abstract: With rare unanimity, the European allies reacted with approval today to the United States missile strike against Iraq.    Britain, Italy and Germany, all of whose leaders were apparently informed about the plans shortly before the strike began, all gave strong backing to the move today despite reports of civilian casualties.

nytimes_articles.headline: Open the G-7's Doors To This Asian Symbol
nytimes_articles.abstract: It is time to breathe a bit of life into that tired old circus, the annual Group of Seven summit meeting. Next month, members of this self-appointed group will sit around in Tokyo, where the host nation and the leaders of the other big industrialized nat

nytimes_articles.headline: SHEIK WAS AWARE OF BOMBING PLOT, U.S. OFFICIALS SAY
nytimes_articles.abstract: Federal law-enforcement authorities in New York concluded that Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, the radical Egyptian cleric, knew details of the plot to detonate bombs across the city and assassinate several officials but were waved off of arresting him at the last minute by the Clinton Administration, Government officials said today.   The officials described the decision -- debated in a series of meetings last Tuesday -- as a hairline call ultimately decided by Attorney General Janet Reno on legal and tactical grounds, including Mr. Abdel Rahman's usefulness as a powerful lens through which authorities examined the murky and violent world of Islamic extremism. Evidence Called 'Fuzzy'    Moreover, as they considered preparing an arrest complaint, the officials concluded that some of the evidence against the sheik was "fuzzy," as one put it, although investigators were convinced -- on the basis of electronic monitoring -- that he knew about the plot. Their information was less clear about his precise role and how directly he was involved in specific actions, like selecting targets.

nytimes_articles.headline: RAID ON BAGHDAD: The White House; Administration Finds Just Keeping a Secret Can Be a Triumph
nytimes_articles.abstract: The unexpected missile strike against Iraq's intelligence headquarters was a result of weeks of intensive planning so secret that no more than five top White House aides had any knowledge of the discussions, Clinton Adminstration officials said today.   By concealing the conclusion that Baghdad was responsible for an assassination plot against George Bush during his visit to Kuwait in April, aides provided a veil of secrecy that gave President Clinton the advantage of surprise when military retribution came. It also helped him appear decisive and resolute in his most significant action yet as Commander in Chief.

nytimes_articles.headline: Thousands March in a Celebration of Gay Pride
nytimes_articles.abstract: With their fists raised in solidarity and their voices celebrating their pride, tens of thousands of gay men, lesbians and their supporters strolled and chanted their way down Fifth Avenue yesterday in a sprawling march that underscored the striking range of gay life in New York City.   Gay social workers, gay soccer players, gay gospel singers, gay Republicans, gay mothers, gay Harlemites, -- they all came together on a humid afternoon for the 24th annual march, which took on an added significance this year because of President Clinton's proposal to allow homosexuals to serve in the military. What Gay America Looks Like    "I feel so moved emotionally," Miriam Ben-Shalom, one of the grand marshals of the parade, said as she watched marchers surge down Fifth Avenue and spectators three-deep jostle for views on the sidewalks. "Look at all the people here. This is America. Do you want to see what gay America looks like? Look on this street."

nytimes_articles.headline: Was This Strike Necessary?
nytimes_articles.abstract: It's easy to appreciate the pressures that drove President Clinton to order an early Sunday morning missile attack on an Iraqi intelligence complex in central Baghdad. And no sympathy need be wasted on Saddam Hussein, whose continued defiance of Security Council resolutions makes him, literally, an international outlaw.    Mr. Clinton's show of force won predictably quick endorsement on Capitol Hill and from allied leaders. But the American people need more information about the reasons for and propriety of Mr. Clinton's action. Was this -- as the Administration contends -- a wise use of force, combining the logic of retaliation and the benefit of pre-empting future terrorist strikes?

nytimes_articles.headline: In Detroit Beating Case, Pillory for Cub Reporter
nytimes_articles.abstract: The judge in a police beating trial here has cited a newspaper intern for contempt for telephoning a juror while testimony was still being heard in the case. But in an unusual twist, the judge ordered the intern, a summer employee of The Detroit News, to serve part of his five-day jail sentence in the courtroom dressed in prison garb.   The judge, who had specifically ordered reporters not to speak with jurors, said while sentencing the intern on Friday that he had mistrusted the newspaper since his childhood. During the McCarthy era, the judge's father defended people accused of being Communists and was harshly criticized by the newspaper.

nytimes_articles.headline: This Time, Yankees Hold Onto The Lead
nytimes_articles.abstract: So many delicious chances had drifted away, so many seemingly insurmountable leads had dissipated on this road trip that the Yankees never felt safe. So when Harold Baines hit a harmless two-out grounder to second that suddenly nicked a clump of dirt and rolled up Pat Kelly's arm with the tying run buzzing home from third in the eighth inning today, the Yankees gasped. Not again. Please, not this again.   Their gasps never turned to groans. Instead, they turned to glee when Kelly deftly fielded the tricky grounder that Steve Howe induced and completed the difficult play to maintain the one-run lead. Then the Yankees exhibited some muscle in the ninth inning, blasting the Baltimore bullpen for three runs on Danny Tartabull's monstrous two-run homer and Don Mattingly's double to escape from Camden Yards with a 9-5 victory. Orioles Cooled Off    They could not wait to gloat, and then leave. Fast.

nytimes_articles.headline: INSIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Haiti Talks Under Way   United Nations diplomats began talks in New York with Haiti's military leader and its exiled President, hoping to restore him to power. Page A3. Tokyo Sends a Message    Japan's leading parties did poorly in Tokyo elections, which were seen as a referendum on the country's national political scandal. Page A3. Rare Latin American Oil Sale    Argentina is taking a step no other Latin American country has tried: selling control of its state oil company to stock-market investors. Page D1. Popular New State Park    In the four weeks since Riverbank State Park opened atop a sewage treatment plant in Harlem, people have been using it in droves. Page B1. Embarrassment of Losses    Mets pitcher Anthony Young's 24th consecutive loss set a major league record. SportsMonday, page C1.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dance in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Terry Creacy and Stephen Koester   Tisch School of the Arts  New York University    Terry Creach and Stephen Koester can be depended on for intriguing repertory and dancing that is explosively physical yet witty. And that was what the two men, who have danced together since 1980, presented Thursday night.

nytimes_articles.headline: Paula R. Kuhl, Michael Graham
nytimes_articles.abstract: Paula Rochelle Kuhl, a daughter of Honey and Harold Kuhl of Merrick, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael Jason Graham, the son of Roberta and Paul Graham of Huntington, L.I. Rabbi Jeremiah Wohlberg performed the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.

nytimes_articles.headline: Editorial Notebook; The Real Clarence Thomas
nytimes_articles.abstract: "I say to myself every day, there but for the grace of God, go I," said Supreme Court nominee Clarence Thomas. He was telling the Senate at his 1991 confirmation hearing of the feelings he had for the busloads of prisoners he watched daily from his courthouse window. The implication was that a Justice Thomas, up from the dirt poverty of Pin Point, Ga., would look out for the underdog, even a convicted one with few rights.    Yet twice in his two terms on the Court, Justice Thomas has argued in dissent that the Eighth Amendment's ban on cruel and unusual punishments should not protect prison inmates. Last year he objected to relief for a prisoner who had suffered, he said, only minor injuries at the hands of his guards: a split lip, loosened teeth, a broken dental plate and the taunting of a supervisor who warned the guards not to have "too much fun." The other day he objected again when the Court held that a prisoner subjected to the fumes of a chain-smoking cellmate might have a constitutional complaint.

nytimes_articles.headline: Elisabeth Klufer, Richard Haber
nytimes_articles.abstract: Elisabeth Joel Klufer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Klufer of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Richard Seth Haber, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney A. Haber of White Plains. Rabbi Beth Singer performed the ceremony at the Water Club in New York.    Ms. Klufer is keeping her name. She is the Eastern sales manager for The National Real Estate Investor and for Shopping Center World, trade magazines for the real estate industry, in New York. She graduated from Sarah Lawrence College.

nytimes_articles.headline: Miss Greenberger and Mr. Rosovsky
nytimes_articles.abstract: Rachel Pam Greenberger, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Norton J. Greenberger of Mission Hills, Kan., was married yesterday to Michael Rosovsky, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Rosovsky of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Morris Margolies and Rabbi Alan Cohen jointly officiated at the Beth Shalom Synagogue in Kansas City, Mo.   Mrs. Rosovsky, 26, is a science and mathematics teacher at Brookwood School in Manchester, Mass. She graduated from the University of Pennsylvania. Her father is a professor of medicine and the chairman of the department of medicine at the Kansas University School of Medicine in Kansas City, Kan.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Scarlet Number: Young Drops 24th
nytimes_articles.abstract: The people asked the silliest of questions.   "Don't you want the record, Anthony?" they asked, wide-eyed, as they hovered over his table. "Wouldn't it be nice to have it? To be in the record books?"

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Jazz Festival; Remembering Birdland
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sometimes things just don't turn out well, despite the best of intentions. On Friday night at Carnegie Hall, "A Lullaby for Birdland," part of the JVC Jazz Festival and a tribute to the musicians who performed at the legendary club during the 1950's and 60's, featured a series of fine groups that did just about nothing. It seemed as if the musicians couldn't hear each other onstage, and the sound in the hall itself was disembodied and ghostlike, as if the musicians were calling in the show over the phone.   The first group to perform consisted of Red Rodney on fluegelhorn, Lee Konitz on alto saxophone, Gerry Mulligan on baritone saxophone, John Lewis on piano, Paul West on bass and Roy Haynes on drums. On "Apple Core," Mr. Rodney presented a bright be-bop solo, and Mr. Mulligan flowed gently. The next tune, a blues, opened with Mr. Lewis's glacial four-choruses and distilled be-bop lyricism. Mr. Mulligan and Mr. Rodney riffed quietly and played with so much ease that the rhythm section's clumsiness could be overlooked for a minute; Mr. Konitz, who was apparently having a bad night, turned in a painfully out-of-tune improvisation.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ex-Deputy Leading Field To Become Schools Chief
nytimes_articles.abstract: Bernard R. Gifford, one of the three remaining candidates under consideration as New York City's next schools chancellor, goes into final interviews with the Board of Education today as the front-runner because he is favored by some board members and so far faces no organized opposition and because the other two finalists have liabilities.   Mr. Gifford, who is a native New Yorker, is a former deputy chancellor in the city who is now teaching at the University of California at Berkeley.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEWS SUMMARY
nytimes_articles.abstract: International A2-7  U.S. CALLS ATTACK A SUCCESS  U.S. officials declared the missile strike on Baghdad's intelligence headquarters a success, saying Iraq's ability to direct terrorist acts worldwide had suffered "a major setback." A1  OBJECT LESSON IN MIDEAST  News analysis: White House officials apparently intended the missile strike on Baghdad as an object lesson for any other government that might be involved in plotting terrorism against the U.S. A1

nytimes_articles.headline: Pattern of Deception Is Seen at Pentagon
nytimes_articles.abstract: Federal investigators have determined that the Pentagon misled Congress about the cost and the necessity of many weapons built in the 1980's to counter the forces of the Soviet Union.   Eight reports from a three-year study by the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, show a pattern of exaggeration and deception by military leaders. The reports, which are scheduled to be discussed this week in a Senate hearing, found that the Pentagon understated the cost of nuclear missiles, overstated the radar-evading ability of new nuclear bombers and exaggerated the threat posed by Soviet defenses.

nytimes_articles.headline: Likely Victors in Nigeria Election Call for Defiance of Military Rule
nytimes_articles.abstract: In what was seen as the strongest challenge to the authority of Nigeria's military rulers in recent memory, a virtual uprising against them was urged today by leaders of the political party whose candidate for president seemed the likely winner in an election this month.   The election was canceled by the military leader, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, who explained his decision by citing what he said was evidence of widespread fraud and vote-tampering in the primaries and in the voting on June 12. On Saturday night, General Babangida announced that there would be new presidential elections and effectively barred the two candidates who had run from running again.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hamlin Treats Victory As More Than Comeback
nytimes_articles.abstract: Shelley Hamlin won the second golf tournament today since she had breast-cancer surgery two years ago, but don't call her courageous or inspirational.   "Determined and stubborn is a better description than courageous or anything else," the 44-year-old Hamlin said today after winning the $450,000 ShopRite L.P.G.A. Classic at the Greate Bay Resort and Country Club. "People come up to me and tell me I'm an inspiration. I'm just an ordinary person."

nytimes_articles.headline: In Week 2, All Roads Lead to the Germans
nytimes_articles.abstract: The second week of The Championships begins with the defending champion facing a challenge that would seem beyond him, but for his magic of a year ago. So no one knows what to expect when Andre Agassi meets the unpredictable serve of Richard Krajicek lat

nytimes_articles.headline: BASEBALL: Sports of The Times; The Small Talk At Macombs Dam
nytimes_articles.abstract: SUNDAY morning, close to noon.   A group of runners sits on weather-beaten bleachers in Macombs Dam Park, a tiny overused fitness oasis nestled in the shadows of Yankee Stadium. The runners have known one another for years; many of them met here at Macombs.

nytimes_articles.headline: World-Weary Becker Is a Kid Again at Play on Grass
nytimes_articles.abstract: It's June, and that means Boris Becker's thoughts, thoughts more often preoccupied with throwing the I Ching than with bashing tennis balls, have lightened, turned to the pleasant prospect of winning Wimbledon.   "Once we get here, once it's June," he said the other day in the midst of a discussion about a terrible spring spent on clotted clay, "I always think I have a good chance."

nytimes_articles.headline: After Losing It All, No Bitterness Shows
nytimes_articles.abstract: Having been indicted, booked, fingerprinted, tried, convicted, ousted as one of New York State's most powerful lawmakers and, last week, cleared by a Federal appeals court, Mel Miller seemed to need only one thing as he talked about his two-and-a-half-year ordeal: a drummer to go bah-dum-dum as he tossed off one-liners.   Of the prosecutor: "Do I want to go over and punch him in the mouth? No. First of all, it's probably a felony."

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: It's difficult for some foundation heads not to think of fund raising at all times. When officers of Amfar, the American Foundation for AIDS Research, told MICHAEL WARD STOUT, president of the Robert Mapplethorpe Foundation, that they wanted to honor him with a dinner, he responded: "It ought to be a fund-raiser. You shouldn't waste the evening."    So be it, they said, and the proceeds of a $250-a-person dinner this evening for 100 guests at the restaurant Ariel & Michael on East 22d Street are to go into Amfar's coffers.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ms. Radomsky And Mr. Bass
nytimes_articles.abstract: Pauline Radomsky, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Radomsky of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Robert Bass, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Bass of Howard Beach, Queens. Rabbi Gerald M. Solomon officiated at Temple Shalom of Electchester in Fresh Meadows, Queens.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Music; Pavarotti Sings, and the Great Lawn Is All Ears
nytimes_articles.abstract: Fame is an intoxicating lure for the multitudes who admire those who have achieved it. In today's opera world, there are few singers as famous as Luciano Pavarotti, and when he gave a free concert in Central Park on Saturday evening, both hard-core opera fans and casual listeners who rarely venture into an opera house flocked to the Great Lawn to bask in the tenor's rich tone and stellar presence. Near the end of the 130-minute concert, the Parks Department estimated the crowd at 500,000, an increase of 100,000 over the estimate provided when the concert began and quadruple the expectation earlier in the day.    Millions more watched the concert on television, nationally on a PBS broadcast and yesterday on a delayed international broadcast. And no doubt it will have a video afterlife, as many of Mr. Pavarotti's televised performances do.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Final 'Dinner With Balanchine' Summarizes a Master's Legacy
nytimes_articles.abstract: In its eight-week tribute to George Balanchine, the New York City Ballet staged 73 ballets from the choreographer's 465-work repertory, staying true to his belief that the material of dance should be dance itself. Yesterday, drawing the grand affair to a close, the company modified that dictum a bit: the material of dance became dance itself plus food, although there was no danger that the art would end up with second billing.   Using a logistical flourish that mirrored both the master's energy and his formal, not-so-simple simplicity, the Balanchine Celebration ended with a six-hour-plus, seven-course program, "Dinner With Balanchine." It was three parts ballet, three parts food and one part film-clip and spoken tribute, with 100 percent effort from hundreds of people.

nytimes_articles.headline: Young Must Master The Learning Curve
nytimes_articles.abstract: Anthony Young is now in the book, a pitcher with the ignominious distinction of losing a major league record 24 consecutive decisions.   He has not seen a victory next to his name in a box score since April 19, 1992, and probably not even Las Vegas at this point would give odds on when fortune and Mets competence will coincide long enough for him to get another.

nytimes_articles.headline: RAID ON BAGHDAD: An Assessment; The Missile' Message
nytimes_articles.abstract: White House officials said today that their only regret about the missile attack on the Iraqi intelligence headquarters was that there was no CNN crew there to broadcast the event live so it could be watched in the Sudan, Iran and other countries suspected of involvement in terrorism.   Administration officials said they had no conclusive evidence that the Sudanese or Iranian intelligence services were involved with the Muslims recently arrested in the New York area and accused of plotting to bomb the United Nations and other sites.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jessica Lipschutz, Edward Deutsch
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jessica Dara Lipschutz, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Lipschutz of Warren, N.J., was married yesterday to Edward Adam Deutsch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Deutsch of Paramus, N.J. Rabbi Gerald Goldman officiated at the Ryland Inn in Whitehouse, N.J.   Mrs. Deutsch, 24, graduated from Princeton University, as did her husband, and received a master's degree in education from Harvard University. Her father is an associate clinical professor of medicine at the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School at Rutgers University in Warren and is also an internist there. Her mother, Susan Lipschutz, is a freelance photographer there.

nytimes_articles.headline: Deedee Rodolitz, J. F. Jacobsohn
nytimes_articles.abstract: Diane Lynn Rodolitz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan J. Rodolitz of Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Jeremy Frederick Jacobsohn, the son of Dr. and Mrs. James S. Jacobsohn of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. Rabbi Sholom Stern officiated at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I.    Mrs. Jacobsohn, 32, is known as Deedee. She graduated from Northwestern University and received a master's degree in history from Harvard University. She is a candidate for a doctoral degree in American and New England studies at Boston University. Her father is the president of Coronet Parts Manufacturing Company, a manufacturer of fluid conductors for industry, in Brooklyn.

nytimes_articles.headline: Gibson Is Message To Bullpen
nytimes_articles.abstract: The transaction will not grab big headlines. The Yankees simply exchanged one thirtysomething left-handed reliever for another when they released Neal Heaton today and recalled Paul Gibson from Class AAA Columbus. But there were intriguing elements to the minor move.   Gibson and Heaton have been friends since they were teen-agers on Long Island and grew up playing baseball with and against each other. They even attended a major league tryout at Yankee Stadium together. There was also the sidelight that Gibson was released by the Mets earlier this month, a fact hard to ignore since Gibson arrived at Camden Yards today carrying a Mets suitcase and garment bag.

nytimes_articles.headline: TENNIS: Rotter on the Court!; Keeping Tabs on the Tabloids at Wimbledon
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Rotters were on the trail of Andre Agassi.   "Who's going to ask about Streisand, then?" grumbled John (Jacko) Jackson, the white-haired, ruddy-faced dean of the wolfpack of British tabloid reporters, who proudly call themselves Rotters after the tenacious German dogs, Rottweilers.

nytimes_articles.headline: Holyfield Plods Way to Victory
nytimes_articles.abstract: It was a bout of such resounding disappointment that dozens of fans left their $300 ringside seats before the final round even started. Riddick Bowe had slipped out of the Convention Center five rounds earlier.   A sluggish, often-winded Evander Holyfield, once the picture of health, plodded his way to a victory over Alex Stewart on Saturday night, but it did nothing for his image or that of the heavyweight division.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Opera; Mozart Comedy Opens Company's 11th Year
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Opera Festival of New Jersey is celebrating its 10th anniversary and has expanded its season to three productions from two. This year's program, running through July 17, includes Mozart's "Magic Flute," Bizet's "Carmen" and Peter Maxwell Davies's "Lighthouse." As in the past, the company has made an effort to represent the 20th century and also has staged all the operas in English. The inaugural performance was "The Magic Flute," at the Lawrenceville School on June 19; Michael Pratt conducted.   Ron Kadri's design for this tale of Freemasonry and sacred ceremony is simple and lucid, favoring pastel colors. The traditional large moon-disk floats in the center; F. Mitchell Dana's lighting supplied green, purple or reddish hues, sometimes a faintly psychedelic spectrum effect. Opaque, crystalline shapes rise to either side in the opening scene; the columns of Sarastro's palace are no more substantial.

nytimes_articles.headline: MILITARY ACCUSED OF LIES OVER ARMS
nytimes_articles.abstract: Government investigators have concluded that military officials misled Congress about the cost, the performance and the necessity of many of the most expensive weapons systems built in the 1980's for nuclear war against the Soviet Union.   The Pentagon understated the cost of nuclear missiles by billions of dollars; it deliberately overstated the radar-evading ability of the new generation of nuclear bombers, and it exaggerated the threat posed by Soviet weapons and defenses, the investigators say. Their findings are in eight secret reports from a three-year study by the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lost Without a Trace; For the Families of Missing Persons, Allies Are Hard to Find and Questions Are Many
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mark David Zeichner vanished from his Queens apartment on a June day eight years ago, abandoning family, friends and all the trappings of a young man's life. His clothes still hung in the closets; his toothbrush leaned against its glass. "It was like somebody disappearing out of their skin," said his mother, Sonia Chusit.   Ever since, these questions have tortured her: Why did he go? Where is he? Is he living on the streets? Was he the hitchhiker she'd just passed? Most importantly, was her son, a manic-depressive who had once attempted suicide, alive?

nytimes_articles.headline: RESULTS PLUS
nytimes_articles.abstract: GOLF  Borrowed Putter Wins for Price  Nick Price, using a borrowed putter, found the touch that eluded him at the United States Open and shot a five-under-par 65 yesteray to win the Greater Hartford Open by a stroke. Price played bogey-free golf for the final 28 holes over the Cromwell, Conn., course and finished the tournament at nine-under 271. Dan Forsman and Roger Maltbie birdied the final hole to finish at eight under. "I can't tell you how much this means to me," Price said. "I played so well last week at the U.S. Open and to end up losing everything on the greens was just so hard to accept especially since I was putting so well recently. I'm just glad I found another putter." Price borrowed a putter from Denis Watson on Friday and started making some putts yesterday. (AP) Colbert Wins Seniors Championship: Jim Colbert got his only bogey of the day on 18 but still won the Senior Players Championship by one stroke over Ray Floyd, who had already finished. Colbert shot a 69 in the final round for a 10-under 278 and collected the $180,000 winner's prize. It was his seventh Senior victory -- but the first major. Floyd shot a 68-279. Al Geiberger was another shot back at 280 after a closing 66. (AP) HORSE RACING  Commander in Chief Takes Irish Derby  Unbeaten Commander in Chief added the Irish Derby to a list of triumphs yesterday in Kildare, Ireland, by holding off a late challenge from French Derby winner Hernando. Commander in Chief, the English Derby winner, and Hernando pulled away from the other nine horses 400 yards from the finish line and turned the $550,000 race into a duel. Pat Eddery, on Commander in Chief, pulled two lengths ahead with 150 yards to go and held off Hernando, ridden by the American jockey Cash Asmussen. (AP) AUTO RACING  Mansell Mistake Helps Fittipaldi  A mistake by Nigel Mansell and Emerson Fittipaldi's own masterful driving in the rain yesterday decided the Budweiser-G.I. Joe's 200 Indy car race. Mansell, the series point leader, started from the pole and led the first 27 laps on the 1.95-mile, nine-turn Portland (Ore.) International Raceway road course, with Fittipaldi never letting the Englishman get as much as a full second ahead. Finally, the pressure paid off for the Brazilian as Mansell, the reigning Formula One champion but an Indy car rookie, braked too late going into the first turn -- a right-hander -- drove into some safety cones and had to stop while a safety worker removed a cone from beneath his Lola-Ford Cosworth. (AP) TRACK AND FIELD  Privalova Excels in European Cup    A British hurdler, Colin Jackson, and a Russian sprinter, Irina Privalova, produced the top performances yesterday on the final day of the European Cup at Olympic Stadium in Rome. Jackson, a European champion and an Olympic silver medalist in Seoul, South Korea, won the 110-meter hurdles in 13.10 seconds, the best time in the world this year. Privalova achieved another world best for the year in the women's 200 meters, winning in 22.30 seconds. France's Marie-Jose Perec, the Olympic 400-meter champion, had the same time as Privalova, but was placed second after judges checked the photo finish. Privalova earlier took the 100-meter race and anchored the Russian victory in the 400-meter relay. (AP) Mutola and Chemoiywo Post Top Times: Mozambique's Maria Mutola and Kenya's Simon Chemoiywo posted the best times in the world this year in their running events at the African championships in Durban, South Africa. Mutola, the reigning world indoor champion at 800 meters, won the 800 in 1 minute 56.39 seconds. She shaved two-tenths of a second off her African record, set several weeks ago in the United States. Chemoiywo won the 5,000 meters in 13:09.68. (AP) SOCCER  Argentine Penalty Kicks Eliminate Brazil  Defending champion Argentina eliminated Brazil on penalty kicks to advance to the semifinals of the America Cup in Guayaquil, Ecuador. After both teams scored the first five kicks, Argentine goalkeeper Sergio Goyoechea stopped Boiadeiro's shot and Jorge Borelli scored the winner. Regulation play ended at 1-1, with Muller scoring for Brazil in the 37th minute and Leo Rodriguez for Argentina in the 69th. "It's a pity that we lose on that Russian roulette that are the penalty kicks," Brazil Coach Carlos Alberto Parreira said.In the semifinals, Argentina will play Colombia on Thursday. Mexico, which beat Peru, 4-2, faces Ecuador Wednesday. (AP) DOG SHOW  Cocker Spaniel First on Staten Island    A 2-year-old black cocker spaniel, Ch. Milru's Patriot, owned by Ruth Muller and Phyllis Tabler, led a field of 1,238 dogs at the Staten Island Kennel Club's 53d all-breed show yesterday in the Wagner College football stadium. "I like the dog's head and top-line and he stood up very well in the heat," said Dr. Michael Manning, judging his first best in show.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bring Russia and Ukraine Into NATO Together
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Talking Sense to Ukraine" (editorial, June 21) makes clear that we first have to start talking sense to ourselves about Ukraine. Your idea of a comprehensive security package for Ukraine is an essential step if we want Ukraine to behave in a way that fits into our own security conceptions and preferences.

nytimes_articles.headline: TRANSACTIONS
nytimes_articles.abstract: Baseball  WEEKEND American League   BALTIMORE ORIOLES -- Placed Sherman Obando, outfielder, on the 15-day disabled list. Called up John O'Donoghue, pitcher, from Rochester of the International League.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rita Wecker and David Brickman
nytimes_articles.abstract: Rita Lynn Wecker, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin R. Wecker of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Meyer Brickman, a son of Dr. Anthony Brickman of Lawrenceville, N.J., and Ravelle Brickman of New York. Rabbi Shlomo Balter officiated at the National Arts Club in New York.   The bride and the bridegroom graduated from the University of Pennsylvania, he cum laude.

nytimes_articles.headline: Visitors Instantly Embrace Rooftop Park
nytimes_articles.abstract: Gaspar Santiago, the mild-mannered director of New York's newest state park, was standing on a plaza between the outdoor pool and the baseball field when he noticed a bag of cheese popcorn in the grass. Nearby, children were shrieking in the giant sprinkler and adults were cheering players in the Tony Fernandez Little League, but nothing could distract Mr. Santiago from that bag of cheese corn.   "Let me just get that before it's all over the place," Mr. Santiago said, stooping like a fussy housekeeper to pick up the cheese corn, and, while he was at it, an unsmoked cigarette, a paper napkin, a candy wrapper, a can and a plastic "I Love New York" bag.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bring Russia and Ukraine Into NATO Together; Too Late for Trust
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   In "Russia Aims Its Oil Weapon" (Op-Ed, June 17), Jerry Hough shows unfamiliarity with the history of Ukrainian and Russian integration. Since the mid-17th century integration between the two nations has resulted in the destruction of Ukrainian temporal and secular institutions, as well as the deaths of millions of people whose crime was to be Ukrainian. Furthermore, Ukrainian culture and language suffered an onslaught of Russification.

nytimes_articles.headline: In New Jersey, Women Study Whitman Bid
nytimes_articles.abstract: Christine Todd Whitman is battling history in her bid to become the first woman to serve as Governor of New Jersey. And while there is no way to gauge whether her sex alone will be a boon, a burden or an irrelevancy in the campaign, it has already begun to generate a statewide debate among women.   For some it is simply a matter of electing a woman for the sake of increasing their numbers in public office. For others it is that as well as the litmus test of issues that have long concerned women, among them abortion, welfare and civil rights. For still others it is a quandary made up of all these things plus the tug of partisan politics.

nytimes_articles.headline: Child Services Can Tear Families Apart
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Family Preservation and Its Victims" (Op-Ed, June 19), a diatribe by Patrick Murphy, Cook County Public Guardian, against family preservation, is based on the flawed premise that child protective services leave hard-working but impoverished families alone, and only intervene when parents, usually drug addicted, beat, rape or torture their children.

nytimes_articles.headline: Valerie Frankel, Glenn Rosenberg
nytimes_articles.abstract: Valerie Ann Frankel, an associate editor at Mademoiselle magazine and author of mystery novels, and Glenn Rosenberg, a product manager at Columbia House, the music catalogue company, both in New York, were married yesterday. Rabbi Michael Paley officiated at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Howard J. Frankel, in Short Hills, N.J.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Jazz Festival; For Gilberto Gil, a Bilingual Birthday
nytimes_articles.abstract: Gilberto Gil, the great Brazilian singer, songwriter, and guitarist, was the host of his own joyous 51st birthday party at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday evening. In a JVC Jazz Festival event that had the informal atmosphere of a family musicale, Mr. Gil was joined by friends who included the fiery Brazilian diva Gal Costa, and Elaine Elias, a Brazilian pianist who led a trio.    Among the handful of Brazilian pop stars of international reputation who emerged from the Brazilian state of Bahia, Mr. Gil reaches the most deeply into the African side of his music's Afro-Caribbean roots. Although his music can be very lyrical, it can also be percussive, and many of his songs have the quality of secularized ceremonial chants. The figure he cut onstage on Saturday was that of wise, sophisticated flower child, part priest, part cultural emissary, from whom music erupts as naturally as water gushing from a tropical spring.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Theater; A Quest for Meaning in India, With a Playful God as a Guide
nytimes_articles.abstract: God is the comeback story of the year in the American theater. As playwrights despair over the nation's health, they increasingly look heavenward (though not necessarily to a Judeo-Christian heaven) for answers that elude them on earth. To the list of recent spiritually inclined dramas that includes "Angels in America," "Redwood Curtain" and "Marisol" can now be added "A Perfect Ganesh," a new play at the Manhattan Theater Club by Terrence McNally, of all unlikely people. Mr. McNally, the urbane and ferociously funny author of "Lips Together, Teeth Apart," "Frankie and Johnny in the Clair de Lune" and "The Lisbon Traviata," here takes a searching, if unfulfilled, journey into the mystical realms of India.   The G word in his title, which, as one line has it, "sounds like a Jewish food," is in fact a reference to the Hindu god Ganesha, who is both a Puck-like character in the play (sweetly acted by Dominic Cuskern, wearing the requisite elephant's head) and a symbol of the transcendence to which Mr. McNally's two American heroines aspire. Margaret Civil (Frances Sternhagen) and Katharine Brynne (Zoe Caldwell), a pair of starchy, 60-ish best friends from Connecticut taking a two-week tour of India, have good reason to seek a new deity, especially one as happy and benevolent as Ganesha. Both women have lost first-born sons in grotesque incidents of skull-crushing violence in Greenwich Village. Both women are temporarily fleeing tired marriages that will soon be ripped apart by new and random tragedies.

nytimes_articles.headline: METRO DIGEST
nytimes_articles.abstract: SPECTER OF TERROR: DEBATE ON ARREST OF A SHEIK   Federal law-enforcement authorities in New York concluded that Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, the radical Egyptian cleric, knew details of a plot to detonate bombs across the city but were waved off arresting him at the last minute by the Clinton Administration, Government officials say. They described the decision as a hairline call ultimately decided by Attorney General Janet Reno on legal and tactical grounds, including Mr. Abdel Rahman's usefulness as a powerful lens through which authorities examine the murky and violent world of Islamic extremism.  Moreover, the officials concluded that some of the evidence against the sheik was "fuzzy." A1.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hammonds Caught Up In Thrust by Orioles
nytimes_articles.abstract: There isn't a more ideal situation for a rookie coming up in June. Baltimore is challenging Toronto, Detroit and New York in an early pennant race and the Orioles have followed a sweep of the Tigers by coming from behind to take two of three from the Yankees.    Coming up is a three-game home stand starting Monday night against the first-place Blue Jays, and 22-year-old Jeffrey Hammonds of Scotch Plains, N.J., can't hide his excitement.

nytimes_articles.headline: RAID ON BAGHDAD: The Overview; U.S. Says Strike Crippled Iraq's Capacity for Terror
nytimes_articles.abstract: Declaring the United States missile attack against Iraq's intelligence headquarters a success, Administration officials said today that Baghdad's ability to direct terrorist acts worldwide had suffered "a major setback."    President Clinton expressed regret that Iraqi civilians had been killed in the raid early today, which was carried out in retaliation for what he said was Iraq's attempt to assassinate former President George Bush during a visit to Kuwait in April. But on the way to church this morning, Mr. Clinton said, "We sent the message we needed to send."

nytimes_articles.headline: New Immigrants Face Racial Hostility
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Your series, "Hidden Economy: Immigrants Underground," beginning June 13, focuses on immigrants from Asia, Latin America and Africa, implying that the relative absence of Europeans distinguishes this latest wave of immigration from its predecessors. This is inaccurate.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: JULIA ROBERTS married the singer-songwriter LYLE LOVETT yesterday at a church in Marion, Ind., the actress's publicist said.   The actress, 25, met Mr. Lovett, 35, when they filmed "The Player" in 1992, said NANCY SELTZER, who represents the actress. It was the first marriage for both. The wedding was planned in two days, Ms. Seltzer said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dance in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Tina Cross and Donna Jewel  Context Hall East Village    When Tina Croll and Donna Jewell shared a program of dances on June 20, the occasion was something of an artistic homecoming for Ms. Croll. In the 1960's and early 70's, she performed at Dance Theater Workshop, the Judson Memorial Church and other important New York dance centers. Then she traveled in Europe and India, after which she settled in Los Angeles in 1982. Last year, she moved back to New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sudan's Leader, Denying Plot, Visits an Icy Egypt
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Sudanese President, Omar Hassan al-Bashir, whom Egyptian authorities accuse of backing this country's Islamic militants, is trying to soothe deteriorating relations with Egypt, whose President, Hosni Mubarak, was reported to be the target of an assassination plot thwarted in New York City last week.   President Bashir arrived in Egypt today to attend a meeting of the Organization of African Unity and to try to speak with President Mubarak. Egyptian officials, however, said late today that the President had not decided whether to receive the Sudanese leader. The Sudan has been accused of being tied to the conspiracy suspects captured last week.

nytimes_articles.headline: Those With AIDS Need Messages of Hope
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   We fear the pessimism of "The Unyielding AIDS Epidemic" (editorial, June 17) creates the misimpression that we have little to offer those who suffer from this terrible disease.

nytimes_articles.headline: Books of The Times; A City of Angels Visited by Earthlier Creatures
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Angel Carver   By Rosanne Daryl Thomas   260 pages. Random House. $20.  Creatures of Habit   Julie Baumgold   294 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $22.   In Brooklyn on the corner of Flatbush and Parker, there stands an empty shoe-repair shop that was once the workplace of a genius, if we are to believe the unusual fable told in "The Angel Carver," by Rosanne Daryl Thomas, whose previous book, "Complications," was published under the pseudonym Prince Charming.

nytimes_articles.headline: University or Trade School?
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Today, the City University of New York's board of trustees is meeting to vote on a proposal, put forward by Chancellor W. Ann Reynolds, to institute a formal review process for all academic programs. The proposal would give Chancellor Reynolds unprecedented life-and-death power over virtually every department and program on the university's 21 campuses. She would be able to override the judgments of faculty, students and the community. She would have, as the writer Toni Morrison said at a public hearing last week, "a license for destruction."

The resolution before the board is the result of a yearlong fight between faculty and students on one side and the central administration on the other. Chancellor Reynolds would like to downsize and reallocate the university's severely diminished resorces. In December, she issued a proposal called the Goldstein report (named for Leon Goldstein, the president of Kingsborough Community College, who headed the panel that issued the report) that called for eliminating 97 degree programs. Most were at the four-year campuses with the highest percentages of African-American and Latino students and were chiefly in the humanities and the arts. The report also called for expansion of the technical and occupational programs, ostensibly to meet the needs of the city's immigrant and minority populations.

nytimes_articles.headline: BASEBALL: Sports of The Times; In Roy Campanella, The Heart of a Hero
nytimes_articles.abstract: ONLY the medical cause of Roy Campanella's death was a surprise: heart attack.   You always thought that when Campy died, it would be from complications of having been a quadriplegic since his car skidded on an icy road in Glen Cove, L.I., and slammed into a telephone pole early in 1958. Or from being a diabetic. Or from pneumonia. Or problems from his gallstone surgery three years ago. But not his heart. Never his heart.

nytimes_articles.headline: Serbs and Croats Mount Joint Attack on Muslim Town
nytimes_articles.abstract: Serbian and Croatian militias, once bitter enemies in the struggle over the carcass of the former Yugoslavia, are fighting together against the mostly Muslim forces of the Bosnian Government near the central town of Maglaj, United Nations officials and radio reports said today.   The radio broadcasts from Sarajevo said defenders of Maglaj were resisting a "joint attack" by units of Bosnian Serbs and Croats. A spokesman for United Nations forces in Zagreb said that the three factions fought on Saturday with artillery, machine guns and small arms. Another United Nations official said that fighting between the Bosnian Serbs and Croats had virtually ceased throughout the country as their militias focused on predominantly Muslim forces, and that United Nations personnel had seen hundreds of Croatian troops in buses passing through areas controlled by the Serbs.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S.-Born Suspect in Bombing Plots: Zealous Causes and Civic Roles
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the winter of 1989, Clement Rodney Hampton-El, the one American-born suspect arrested thus far in New York's terrorist bombing plots, was back home in a hospital bed in Brooklyn, proudly recuperating from leg and arm wounds he suffered as a fervid Black Muslim combatant in the far-off Afghanistan war.   "Many people have come here to see who this Rambo is after all," a visitor recalled Mr. Hampton-El's declaring zealously. "I tell them it's something they will have to decide in their own mind."

nytimes_articles.headline: Inishmore Island Journal; On Europe's Edge, Island Sees Tourism as Lifeline
nytimes_articles.abstract: The fiercely independent people of this limestone rock, the largest of the three Aran Islands on the western edge of Europe, recall that in the old days the fishermen did not bother to learn to swim because that would only prolong the agony of drowning.   Now, the fishing industry has shrunk because of competition from Spanish and other fleets, and the 2,000 people of the islands acknowledge that they will have to learn to swim in the bureaucratic sea of paperwork for European Community financing programs in Brussels if they are to keep these islands worth living on. Last year the islanders, who have had television only since 1975, voted against the accord on European political union known as the Maastricht treaty, though Irish voters as a whole approved it by a wide margin.

nytimes_articles.headline: Essay; Slapping Saddam's Wrist
nytimes_articles.abstract: The most sought-after document in the capital today is the "military options list" presented to President Clinton after the F.B.I. and C.I.A. determined that the Government of Iraq had tried to assassinate a former U.S. President.   What were the Clinton choices after he saw the solid evidence that Saddam had tried to exact vengeance for his Desert Storm defeat? Forget the unrealistic extremes of doing nothing, or of sending a half-million men back to the Middle East to finish George Bush's half-done job.

nytimes_articles.headline: Victor Maddern; Actor, 67
nytimes_articles.abstract: Victor Maddern, a veteran British character actor, died on Tuesday in London. He was 67 and lived in Suffolk in southeastern England.   The cause was cancer, The Times of London reported.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Television; Survivors Lost in Space But Tethered to Hitchcock
nytimes_articles.abstract: Finally getting around to Mondays as it continues to flesh out a complete prime-time schedule, Fox Broadcasting is falling back on a television staple: movies. Expanding to a weekly series, "Fox Night at the Movies" will offer both theatrical releases -- last Monday's was "The Babe" starring John Goodman -- and made-for-television movies. Tonight's premiere, at 8, is "Lifepod," which, though set in the year 2168, is "inspired by" the 1944 Alfred Hitchcock film "Lifeboat."   "Lifeboat," adapted by Jo Swerling from a John Steinbeck story, was about shipwreck survivors drifting about the ocean during World War II. Its extraordinary cast included Tallulah Bankhead, Walter Slezak, Hume Cronyn and Canada Lee. "Lifepod," written by Pen Densham ("Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves") and M. Jay Roach, is about survivors of a spaceliner explosion drifting through space beyond the range of search cruisers. Its serviceable cast is headed by Ron Silver and Robert Loggia. Mr. Silver directed.

nytimes_articles.headline: 39 Immigrants Rescued In Three Raids in Queens
nytimes_articles.abstract: In raids on three houses in Queens yesterday, the police freed 39 Asian immigrants held captive in Queens and were considering charges against a "handful" of Asian gang members suspected of smuggling them into the country.   The first raid began shortly after 11 A.M., when officials rescued about 15 men from a squat brick house at 164-30 73d Avenue in Fresh Meadows. In the other raids, they freed 21 men and 5 women from a house at 202-10 50th Avenue in Bayside and two men at 133-34 Blossom Avenue in Flushing. The immigrants were taken into police custody, the officials said. They would not say where.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Remember nature hikes and swims in frigid lakes, compulsory letters home, baseball games and cabin pranks, first kisses and, finally, not wanting to say goodbye at the end of camp?    Sixteen songwriters do. They include JAMIE BERNSTEIN THOMAS, a daughter of Leonard Bernstein, DAVID LAWRENCE, a son of Steve Lawrence and Eydie Gorme, and ROBBY MERKIN, musical director for "Sesame Street," and they have written songs for a show called "Everything About Camp (Almost)." The musical revue will be put on by Tada, a nonprofit children's theater company at 120 West 28th Street, from July 16 to Aug. 16.

nytimes_articles.headline: Buenos Aires Journal; Item: Menem Meets Top Model; Today It's Clinton
nytimes_articles.abstract: Much of Argentina acted like an infatuated teen-ager this month when Germany's top model, Claudia Schiffer, arrived to promote a local lingerie company. Troops of reporters and admirers raced after her Mercedes-Benz as part of the excitement that was dubbed Schiffermania and made her front-page news for days.   As is his style, President Carlos Saul Menem was not to be left out. Although talk shows paid $15,000 for her appearance, President Menem held two private meetings with the tall 22-year-old blonde: a 20-minute meeting at the presidential palace and then a private lunch at the presidential residence.

nytimes_articles.headline: METRO DIGEST
nytimes_articles.abstract: MAN CONFESSES TO SERIES OF KILLINGS   A 34-year-old unemployed Long Island landscaper, arrested after the New York State police discovered a body in the back of his pickup truck, has confessed to killing at least 15 prostitutes, many from New York City, and burying their bodies in remote areas, the state police said. The discovery came after a chase that began with a traffic violation. A1. NEIGHBORS OFFER CLUES TO SUSPECT   Neighbors of the suspect, Joel Rifkin, who lived in East Meadow, L.I., question how little they really knew about him. Several described him as "quiet" and "pleasant." Others called him a "loner" who, when angry, would leave in his pickup truck. B5. NEW YORK CITY

nytimes_articles.headline: Books of The Times; From the Closed Mind to the Body
nytimes_articles.abstract: Love and Friendship  By Allan Bloom  590 pages. Simon & Schuster. $25.

nytimes_articles.headline: Space Station Survives a Second Time in Congress
nytimes_articles.abstract: Responding to a vigorous White House lobbying campaign, the House tonight narrowly preserved financing for the Freedom Space Station.   The defeat of an amendment to kill the station virtually assures another year of construction for the $25 billion project, but its razor-thin margin of 196 to 220 means that the station is likely to face annual life-and-death battles as expensive science research continues to lose support among deficit-conscious lawmakers.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Faces Include Raider Ismail
nytimes_articles.abstract: When training camps open next month, among the notable new faces in new places will be Joe Montana with Kansas City, Reggie White with Green Bay and Jim McMahon with Minnesota.   Add Rocket Ismail to the list.   On July 11, the Raiders will be the first team to open camp, and Ismail is expected to be there. The target date for his signing with the Raiders is July 6, but it could happen late this week.

nytimes_articles.headline: CUNY Board Gives Backing To a Redesign
nytimes_articles.abstract: Facing a crisis of soaring enrollments and declining finances, the trustees of the City University of New York yesterday unanimously approved a complex plan to streamline the 21-college system and lay the foundation for growth into the next century.   After months of intense, often bitter debate in and outside the university, the trustees voted 13-to-0 for a plan that makes all academic programs subject to a regular efficiency review and gives the university's Chancellor, W. Ann Reynolds, the authority to set the criteria for passing and failing those reviews.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cheap Seats? Nah, N.B.A. Prefers Business Class
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Phoenix Suns-Chicago Bulls finals lacked for little in the way of competition except Chicago presented no corporate rival to the America West Arena. The new arena, named for the Phoenix-based airline, vied for national attention with the decrepit, ancient Chicago Stadium. No contest there.    Not having a corporate name for the old place seemed so quaint, so old-fashioned, so . . . out of touch with reality.

nytimes_articles.headline: Large Earthquakes Can Trigger Later Tremors Many Miles Away
nytimes_articles.abstract: LARGE earthquakes can trigger tiny ones hundreds of miles away hours, days and even weeks later, scientists say.   Such remote earthquakes are small and pose no danger to people or structures, the researchers said, but they do raise profound questions about the causes of earthquakes and the hidden structures within the earth's crust.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bombing Baghdad Was Not Enough
nytimes_articles.abstract:
While the attack on the Baghdad headquarters of the Iraqi intelligence service is symbolically important, demonstrating that President Clinton is prepared to use force -- and to so independently -- a larger vision and further action is required.

Our policy toward the Persian Gulf has been in limbo since the cease-fire in 1991. It has been shaped largely by the hope that the limited use of force combined with the United Nations's sanctions and embargo will force Saddam Hussein from power.
