nytimes_articles.headline: Street Vendor Crackdown Isn't Halfhearted
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   In "Unlicensed Peddlers, Unfettered Dreams" (front page, June 14), your description of Mayor David N. Dinkins's announcement of the crackdown on illegal street vendors and their suppliers as halfhearted inaccurately characterizes New York City's most comprehensive street-vendor policy in more than 50 years.

nytimes_articles.headline: 2 Men Held In a Scheme With A.T.M.
nytimes_articles.abstract: The arrests of two men accused of setting up a bogus automatic teller machine were announced today by Federal officials, who said the two were outsmarted by the very technology they employed to bilk others of more than $100,000.   Federal officials say that after obtaining secret codes with the bogus bank machine they installed in a Connecticut shopping mall in April, the two men used the information to raid customer accounts through real automatic tellers. As a matter of course, cameras took their pictures at the real machines, which is how they were identified.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Most people are against discrimination. They don't want to hate. They just need to see that we are their friends and neighbors." -- JEN RAY a lesbian college teacher in Idaho.  [ A10:3. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ending 15 months of marital limbo and putting to rest rumors that they might reconcile, the DUKE and DUCHESS OF YORK announced on Monday that they had reached a formal separation agreement, The Associated Press reported. The couple has lived apart since March 1992.   The announcement increased the likelihood that the Duke, 33, the second son of Queen Elizabeth II, and his wife, the former Sarah Ferguson, also 33, would seek a divorce after the two-year waiting period required by British law. They have been married for seven years.

nytimes_articles.headline: 4 NETWORKS AGREE TO OFFER WARNINGS OF VIOLENCE ON TV
nytimes_articles.abstract: Hoping to stave off a federally imposed system of ratings for violence on television, the nation's four broadcast networks have agreed to provide a warning to parents that would be put on the air just before shows laden with mayhem come on.    The warning would also be made available to newspapers and magazines that publish television listings, allowing them to establish what would amount to a special coding for violent shows.

nytimes_articles.headline: London Journal; A Dismal 'Season,' Right Down to Ziggy (the Rat)
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Tower Bridge opens in the heat and gets stuck. Prince Charles hurts his back playing polo and misses the Procession of the Most Noble Order of the Garter. The British soccer team loses -- actually loses -- to the Americans.   It's been that kind of "season" in England this year. At a time when the parties are in full swing and the British are out there earnestly trying to have fun, with more ceremonies and horse formations than the Queen can wave a white glove at, from the races at Ascot to the Royal Regatta at Henley, things just keep going awry.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article on Saturday about testimony given before a United States Senate subcommittee by two former employees of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield -- Joan Boyle and William Fuessler -- referred incorrectly to a statement about them from Empire's current chairman, Harold E. Vogt. He said he had never met the two, who gave the first public evidence that Empire had intentionally misled the New York State Legislature and Insurance Department. But Mr. Vogt did not say that Empire's acting chief executive, Donald L. Morchower, had never met them.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Finalist for Schools Chancellor Withdraws
nytimes_articles.abstract: The search for New York City's next Schools Chancellor was thrown into 11th-hour turmoil yesterday when Bernard R. Gifford, a University of California professor who was one of three finalists and appeared to be the preferred candidate of several board members, unexpectedly withdrew from consideration, said city and school officials and Dr. Gifford's associates.   Dr. Gifford faxed a one-page letter to school officials yesterday afternoon outlining his decision, said a senior city official who said the letter had been read to him. Dr. Gifford cited personal and business conflicts as the reason for his withdrawal, said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mood Swings for Mets Have Already Started
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Mets have entered the final stages of their audition for Dallas Green. Acts have been seen and evaluated. And the recasting, the manager said today, will be extensive.   "There are going to be thousands of stories to write," Green told reporters before tonight's game against the Marlins. "Change positions. Trade players. I'm ready."

nytimes_articles.headline: Book Notes
nytimes_articles.abstract: Turtle Bay's Last Effort   When Turtle Bay Books was summarily shut down by Random House Inc. in February, little remained besides wounded pride, six angry employees, and a list of orphaned books that the editors swore would have turned the young imprint around.    The employees scattered; some were absorbed into other Random House divisions, and Joni Evans, who had been awarded the Turtle Bay imprint after being removed as head of Random House's adult trade division, began working the telephones and pondering her future.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mets' Uncle Dwight, Marlins' Nephew Gary
nytimes_articles.abstract: Rhetoric is the day's greatest entertainment for the Mets. The manager endlessly promises changes, today pledging to send players marching as of the All-Star Game break, 12 days away. The players argue back and forth about who should be traded and who shouldn't. And then, of course, there are the great debates with the soap opera twists, today's version of which was: Will Uncle Dwight ever get to play with nephew Gary?   "It's going to happen," Gary Sheffield said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Suspect Described as a Loner Who Never Left Home
nytimes_articles.abstract: Removed from his world, his head pounding and his glasses taken from him, Joel Rifkin watched the preparations for his arraignment as 17 armed guards filled the courtroom where he was charged with second-degree murder today.   Agape, he said nothing, avoiding the eyes of his 71-year-old mother, Jeanne, and his 31-year-old sister, Jan, whom he had phoned from jail the night before. Since he last saw them, Mr. Rifkin has gone from a nondescript unemployed landscaper who had once tended the William J. Casey estate to a suspected serial killer who, the police said, has confessed to killing 17 prostitutes.

nytimes_articles.headline: As Mississippi Swells, Havoc in the Heartland
nytimes_articles.abstract: Not since the days of the Johnson Administration and the nights of go-go dancers doing the "Swim" has the Mississippi River seemed so high and mighty.   From St. Louis to St. Paul, a 500-mile stretch of the Mississippi has been closed to nearly all commercial traffic because of some of the highest flood levels since 1965, the record year.

nytimes_articles.headline: Insurance Regulator to Reply To Criticism Over Blue Cross
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a stark rebuttal to the criticism leveled at him by United States Senate investigators, the New York State Insurance Superintendent, Salvatore R. Curiale, is prepared to tell a Senate subcommittee on Wednesday that his department diligently monitored Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield and that the insurer's financial troubles have been caused less by mismanagement than by problems in the health insurance system.   "Contrary to the charge that we were 'paralyzed by fear' of regulating Empire, we proceeded on a course that was designed to reduce and even eliminate New York State's dependence on Empire," Mr. Curiale wrote in testimony prepared for delivery before the Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.  Department Criticized    On Friday, the subcommittee issued a strongly worded report in which it blamed Empire for "gross mismanagement" and criticized the Insurance Department for missing even the most obvious signs of trouble. The department behaved more like "a cheerleader for Empire's cause" than an "aggressive regulator," the report said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rebel Attack in India Kills 32
nytimes_articles.abstract: Guerrillas of the Naga tribe in India's northeast ambushed an Indian Army convoy today and killed at least 32 people in one of their biggest strikes against a military target, officials said.   "It was a massive operation and well laid," said Haresh Goswami, the Chief Secretary of Manipur state where the attack was carried out as the convoy traveled through thick forests.

nytimes_articles.headline: For Many, Human Rights Mean Life Itself; A Persistent Wrong
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   The United States has one glaring weakness in attempting to lead the world conference on human rights in Vienna and to distinguish itself from such countries as China, Iran and Vietnam (The Week in Review, June 20). On the issue of capital punishment, the United States is closer to those countries it seeks to condemn than to its traditional Western allies.

nytimes_articles.headline: For No.1 and No.2, The Court's Reserved
nytimes_articles.abstract: Will you hit with me today? Steffi Graf seemed to ask her good friend. .I'd be glad to, Jennifer Capriati seemed to reply. .Graf reserved the court for 2 P.M. Tuesday. They both knew to be on time, because they only had it for 75 minutes. It's a gras

nytimes_articles.headline: Knicks Can't Dial Those Radio Trades
nytimes_articles.abstract: Soon after the Knicks followed the Cleveland Cavaliers onto the Bulls' list of playoff victims, the rumor mill -- also known as Wishful Thinker's Anonymous -- came up with the obvious solution for both teams. The Knicks would trade Charles Oakley and Hubert Davis to the Cavaliers for Mark Price.   The Cavaliers would get their desperately needed tough rebounder and shooting guard, while the Knicks would solve their most pressing deficiency, a point guard who can create and score.

nytimes_articles.headline: On Brink of Collapse, Negotiations on Haiti Are Suddenly Revived
nytimes_articles.abstract: After appearing to be on the verge of collapse, United Nations-led talks on Haiti's political crisis were suddenly revived yesterday with the announcement by the country's army commander that he was eager to discuss conditions for preparing the return of the ousted President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.   The commander, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, made the statement at a news conference on Governors Island in New York harbor, where the talks are being held. It lent hope to diplomats and advisers to Father Aristide that the negotiations, which were thought to be dead as late as yesterday morning, could produce a breakthrough in the country's 21-month-old political stalemate.

nytimes_articles.headline: Space Station Wins Reprieve On Second Vote in the House
nytimes_articles.abstract: Responding to a vigorous White House lobbying campaign, the House has narrowly preserved financing for the space station.

nytimes_articles.headline: Personal Health
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE two most common reasons for major surgery in the United States involve a woman's childbearing organs. No. 1 is Caesarean section, in which the womb is opened to deliver a child, and No. 2 is hysterectomy, in which the womb is removed, ending a woman's childbearing ability.   Although the number of Caesareans has risen in recent years, publicity about unnecessary gynecological surgery seems to have led to a drop in the number of hysterectomies. In 1990, the latest year for which data are available, about 590,000 American women had hysterectomies, down from the annual peak of about 750,000 a decade ago. But many experts believe the number of hysterectomies is still far too high.

nytimes_articles.headline: How St. Louis Gives Young People Hope
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   I commend you for "Wanted: Summer Jobs for Teens" (Topics of The Times, June 17). Anyone who thinks we can turn our backs on a significant portion of our young people today and not suffer for it tomorrow is mistaken. You call for action from business. You may be surprised to learn that St. Louis lawyers, and lawyers across the country, are working to that end.

nytimes_articles.headline: Metzenbaum Says He Won't Seek 4th Senate Term
nytimes_articles.abstract: Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum of Ohio, sometimes irascible, often confrontational and always committed to liberalism, announced today that he would not seek election to a fourth term next year.   Mr. Metzenbaum, a 76-year-old Democrat known for his advocacy of the poor, the aged, organized labor and consumers, said his decision was based on a desire to spend more time with his family. "While I will retire my seat," he said in a speech on the Senate floor, "I will not retire my views or retire my voice."

nytimes_articles.headline: Still Not Good Enough on Iraq
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Clinton Administration claims to have "compelling" circumstantial evidence that Baghdad authorized the failed assassination attempt on George Bush last April. But the evidence it has produced after three days seems too thin to justify the cruise missile attack on Iraq's intelligence headquarters last weekend. Surely the Administration does not intend to usher in an age when nations feel free to fire weapons at each other's cities based on unilateral assertions that intelligence evidence justifies it.   President Clinton said right after the attack that he had acted because of intelligence evidence that Iraq was behind the assassination attempt. The next day the U.S. presented its circumstantial case to the United Nations; bomb materials seized were like those used by Iraqi intelligence in the past, and the captured conspirators believed they had been working for Iraqi intelligence. Yesterday Mr. Clinton said the evidence "clearly indicated" Iraq's responsibility. But nothing new had been presented.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. and Allies Feud on Economic Goals
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United States, Japan and Germany are at loggerheads over an American proposal that the Group of Seven industrial nations set specific targets for annual economic growth when they meet next week in Tokyo, Western officials said today.   They said Japan and Germany have opposed Washington's calls for setting a 3 percent target for economic growth and setting a ceiling on the size of each country's trade deficit or surplus.

nytimes_articles.headline: Uneven Containment : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Iraq is to be punished for its dream of ruling the Middle East and Iran for driving forward the "crashing wave of Islam." Serious crimes, indeed. But does the United States have any right to impose its will in distant lands and that, too, in an

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Says Bomb-Plot Suspects Talked of Blowing Up Manhattan Jewelry District
nytimes_articles.abstract: Conspirators in the foiled bombing plot to blow up the United Nations, Hudson River tunnels and the Federal building in Manhattan talked of bombing the 47th Street diamond district to kill Jews, a Federal prosecutor told a judge yesterday.   The prosecutor also said that the conspirators were aiming to explode their bombs before the rent came due on the Queens garage where they were mixing the chemicals "and that's before the end of the month."

nytimes_articles.headline: Bridge
nytimes_articles.abstract: The playoffs to determine the 1993 United States teams ended here Monday night with an East Coast squad exacting revenge for an earlier defeat. David Berkowitz of Old Tappan, N.J., Larry Cohen of Little Falls, N.J., Sam Lev of Forest Hills, Queens, Cliff Russell of Miami, Marty Bergen of Farmingdale, L.I., and Eric Rodwell of Naperville, Ill., won the final match by 119 imps, and will go to Chile in September along with a team that includes Michael Becker of Tenafly, N.J.   The losers were Neil Chambers of Schenectady, N.Y., John Schermer of Seattle, John Mohan of Santa Monica, Calif., Roger Bates of Mesa, Ariz., Mike Passell of Dallas, and Andy Goodman of San Francisco, who had beaten the Berkowitz team in semifinal play four days earlier.

nytimes_articles.headline: The View From Istanbul : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "The Example of Cyprus" (Letters, June 11): .Panayotis Dracos either prefers to forget the facts or twist them to fit his own version of truth. It was the extremist elements of the Greek Army and Cypriot Greeks who started the "

nytimes_articles.headline: Murdoch Gets Waiver From the F.C.C. to Buy The New York Post
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Federal Communications Commission voted, 2 to 1, today to give Rupert Murdoch the permanent waiver he needs to acquire The New York Post, a day before his management agreement with a bankruptcy court to operate the newspaper was scheduled to expire.   The vote, which came after weeks of wrangling within the F.C.C., sets the stage for Mr. Murdoch to re-acquire the tabloid that he was forced to sell five years ago in order to satisfy Federal regulations that bar a company from owning a newspaper and a television station in the same market.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Museum Is in Beijing, but Who Will See It?
nytimes_articles.abstract: For years, the last place to look for a modern display of Chinese art was in China. Now that may be changing with the opening of China's first Western-style museum here, more than a dozen years after its original sponsor first conceived of it.    The Arthur M. Sackler Museum of Art and Archeology, which opened in Beijing on May 27, has joined a string of Sackler galleries and museums around the world. This one primarily displays relics and fossils discovered by Chinese archeologists.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: It may not be a stately home, but MARSHA MARTIN said she could think of no better place for her farewell party than a New York City shelter for the homeless. Dr. Martin, who was the director of the Mayor's Office on Homelessness and Single Room Occupancy Housing, went to Washington earlier this month to be the executive director of the Interagency Council on the Homeless. The council, whose chairman is Henry G. Cisneros, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, is an independent Government agency that reviews all Federal activities and programs for the homeless.    On Monday evening, about 75 friends and colleagues, many of them from city government, went to the men's shelter at 8 East Third Street, which Dr. Martin said had been transformed from one of the city's most disreputable centers into a transitional residence for homeless men recovering from drug and alcohol abuse.

nytimes_articles.headline: Uneven Containment : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "Keep Iraq and Iran Contained" (Opinion, June 23):.A.M. Rosenthal's shamelessly biased articles add to the existing confusion in the Middle East. He praises the American administration's "dual containment" policy toward I

nytimes_articles.headline: Glyndebourne's London Season
nytimes_articles.abstract: If London can't go to Glyndebourne, then Glyndebourne comes to London, if without evening dress, black tie and picnic baskets. .London doesn't go to Glyndebourne this summer because the old theater on the picturesque Christie estate in Sussex is being

nytimes_articles.headline: Legacy of a Schools Chancellor; Fernandez's Changes May Not Live On After His Departure
nytimes_articles.abstract: As Joseph A. Fernandez moves out of the Chancellor's office at 110 Livingston Street and packs for the long drive back to Florida, he leaves behind a school system that is remarkably transformed, yet remarkably the same.   During his stormy three-and-a-half-year tenure as one of the highest-paid school officials in the country, he brought about dozens of reforms, large and small, at a rapid pace -- from the distribution of condoms in high schools, to the creation of more than 30 small theme high schools scheduled to open by the fall.   As the Board of Education prepares to appoint a new Chancellor -- a decision that could come as soon as tonight -- Mr. Fernandez and his supporters are convinced that, despite a city budget crisis, he created a model reform administration and sowed the seeds of a renaissance in public education.

nytimes_articles.headline: Officers in Nigeria to Retire To Protest Scrapping of Vote
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a highly unusual challenge to Nigeria's military Government, at least 30 officers holding the rank of colonel and above said they would retire from the armed forces in protest against Gen. Ibrahim Babangida's decision to annul this country's recent presidential election, a civilian official with close ties to the military said today.   The National Concord, an independent newspaper owned by Moshood Abiola, a wealthy industrialist and the presidential candidate of the Social Democratic Party, said today that about 14 colonels and 8 brigadier generals had "opted for early retirement."

nytimes_articles.headline: Eyebrows, and Issue Of Color, Are Raised
nytimes_articles.abstract: Rock Newman is getting ready to play the race card.   Newman, who favors dashikis when appearing in places where there is a crowd and who orchestrated Riddick Bowe's victory tour in Somalia and the Vatican, is now telling the boxing world it is looking for a Great White Hope.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1943: Cologne Ravaged : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: LONDON - [From our New York edition:] A huge fleet of British bombers made a savage attack last night [June 28] on Cologne, industrial and commercial German city on the Rhine. Tonight German troops and civil defense patrols were still hard at work trying

nytimes_articles.headline: Mercer Is Charged With Trying to Fix a Fight
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ray Mercer was arraigned yesterday on a charge of sports bribery, accused of repeatedly offering Jesse Ferguson $100,000 to lose during their Feb. 6 heavyweight fight at Madison Square Garden.   District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said Mercer, 32, was arrested Sunday in Indianapolis and was charged yesterday in Manhattan. He was released on his own recognizance despite a request of $10,000 bail by the District Attorney's office.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Spy Who Knew Too Much
nytimes_articles.abstract:
President Clinton's directive for a sweeping review of the rules governing official secrecy is likely to be rendered meaningless by the British Government's embargo on declassifying its intelligence records.

Under the terms of the Anglo-American intelligence-sharing agreement signed during World War I, the unilateral release of any classified information is prohibited. This secret pact prevents the United States National Archives from declassifying 500 boxes of the wartime records of the Office of Strategic Services, the predecessor of the C.I.A.

nytimes_articles.headline: Grand Prix Racing: 1993 Is Shaping Up Great Despite FISA
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a statement that surprised many in the sport, the pros and fans alike, Bernie Ecclestone, the head of the Formula One constructors' group, said that Grand Prix racing is show-biz. The question is, how many drivers, like some professional wrestlers, wo

nytimes_articles.headline: Books of The Times; Black and White Together and Apart
nytimes_articles.abstract: To learn what it means to be black in the United States today, Walt Harrington, a white staff writer for The Washington Post Magazine, decided to crisscross the country and ask scores of black people what they thought and how they felt about their lives. Bidding goodbye to his wife, Keran, who is black, and their two children, he started from their home near Washington and, during three trips in his old Isuzu Trooper through the Deep South, the urban North and the Western states, he covered 25,000 miles on his voyage of discovery.    In "Crossings," he confirms what most of us already know or surmise: blacks and whites dwell in separate worlds. Even in a democracy, trying to break down this divide remains, as Gunnar Myrdal called it in his classic study a half-century ago, "An American Dilemma." Nevertheless, Mr. Harrington adds the skill of an engaged reporter, a personal stake in his subject and the ability to find fresh voices to talk openly about themselves and multi-racialism.

nytimes_articles.headline:
ROWING;
Women-on-Thames, in Sculls and Competing
nytimes_articles.abstract:
The Henley Royal Regatta, "this beautiful pageant of English life," as Winston Churchill described the oldest of all rowing events, was first raced on this straight stretch of the River Thames in 1839. Changes have come in equipment and training methods in the 154 years since, but for the most part, the regatta remained a male preserve.

Until this year. For the first time, female single scullers will race in a full regatta event.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1918: Dugout Delivery : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: PARIS - The Y.M.C.A. has turned newsboy. Up along the Marne River the Y.M.C.A. has tackled the job of delivering Paris newspapers to the American soldiers, getting them even to the fellows who are lying on their backs in advanced posts out toward No Man's

nytimes_articles.headline: Prague Fears Being Migrant Trail's Last Stop
nytimes_articles.abstract: A 31-year-old farmer from Yugoslavia, Mazlun Buragi, stepped off a scruffy bus onto the well-kept square here after a four-country, five-day journey, and with 50 other disheveled passengers tried to arrange a taxi for his crossing into Germany.   An ethnic Albanian from Kosovo Province, dressed in a heavy leather jacket and with a peace sign tattooed on one hand, Mr. Buragi said he was fleeing conscription by the Serbian authorities.

nytimes_articles.headline: Spending Will Get Us Out of This
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "A Budget Too Much Like Perot's" (editorial, June 23), coming on the eve of the Senate vote on the Clinton Administration's proposed budget, is a salutary reminder, in the midst of our almost total preoccupation with reducing the Federal deficit, that the ultimate purpose of all these efforts is to increase the resources that we devote to investment, both private and governmental. Cutting the high rate of Federal Government borrowing is a necessary condition; but there is no basis for confidence that it would be sufficient.

nytimes_articles.headline: Munoz, Yanks' Big Kid, Does Job
nytimes_articles.abstract: The kid didn't get nervous when they made the call to the bullpen late last night. When the Yankees made him a reliever in spring training, Bobby Munoz figured that, one day, he'd have to face situations like these. He just didn't expect it to happen so soon.   In the seventh inning, there was a tied score in a tight division contest, the Yankees against the Detroit Tigers, and Manager Buck Showalter wanted Munoz, his 25-year-old rookie, to pitch New York out of a jam. Showalter went to Steve Howe first, with two outs and the bases loaded and the Yankees ahead, but Howe walked in the tying run.

nytimes_articles.headline: Theater in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lovechild  Irish Arts Center 553 West 51st Street Manhattan By Gerard Stembridge; directed by Nye Heron; musical arrangements and original compositions by Nico Kean; set by David Raphel; lighting by Judith Daitsman; costumes by Carla Gant; choreography, Josephine McNamara; sound by Mr. Kean; vocals by Susan McKeown; production stage manager, Elizabeth English; production technician, Adrienne Walsh; production assistant, Joanna Sykes; puppet design and construction by Maria Murray and Edith Pieperhoff. Presented by the Irish Arts Center, Jim Sheridan, chairman; Mr. Heron, artistic director; Marianne Delaney, executive director. WITH: Malcolm Adams, Rosemary Fine, Michael Judd, Mac Orange and Marian Quinn.

nytimes_articles.headline: An Extra Shot for Anthony: Knicks in Summer League
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Knicks announced yesterday they would be hosts again to the Doral Arrowwood New York Summer League at the Westchester County Center in White Plains. Because of the league's success last year, the field has been expanded from four teams to six teams.   The league consists of squads representing the Knicks, the New Jersey Nets, the Boston Celtics, the Philadelphia 76ers and, new this year, the Washington Bullets and the Milwaukee Bucks.

nytimes_articles.headline: JAPANESE PARTY HIT BY NEW BLOW
nytimes_articles.abstract: Just when Japan's governing party thought that its fortunes could not take another turn for the worse, the mayor of one of northern Japan's largest cities was arrested today and charged with accepting more than $900,000 in bribes in return for fixing government contracts.   Toru Ishii, the mayor of Sendai and until recently the head of the Japan's powerful Association of Mayors, was charged with directing huge public works projects to several construction companies in return for cash.

nytimes_articles.headline: To These Children, Border's No Barrier
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ever since Phoebe Watson showed up in 1948 to teach in this tiny village carved from the sage and mesquite along the Mexican border, the elementary school in Columbus has had a policy of truly open enrollment: more than half its 330 students come in buses from Las Palomas, the Mexican town just two miles away.    "I just never said no to any child who came in from Palomas," said Mrs. Watson, now retired as the school's principal but serving, at the age of 82, as Mayor. "They needed schooling. I wasn't going to be an immigration officer. I didn't care what their birth certificate said."

nytimes_articles.headline: Subplots Will Be Varied in Men's Quarterfinals
nytimes_articles.abstract: When it comes to the men's quarterfinals this year at Wimbledon, there's an apparent mismatch, a friendly match, a grudge match and a match that wasn't supposed to happen.   Cedric Pioline is not a name that springs to mind when potential Grand Slam quarterfinalists are discussed. Particularly not here at Wimbledon, where a Frenchman with clay-court expertise is unheralded at best and, according to his opponent, Stefan Edberg, a dangerous floater at worst.

nytimes_articles.headline: Unrelated Kidney Donors Win Growing Hospital Acceptance
nytimes_articles.abstract: FOR most of her life, Sarah Parsons has known that a hereditary disease would eventually destroy her kidneys and that she would need a transplant.   But what she did not know and would never have guessed was that when her kidneys finally failed, her sister-in-law and three casual friends would, with no prompting, each offer her one of their kidneys and that one of these friends would end up being the donor.

nytimes_articles.headline: Negotiators in Congress Fail To Agree on Military Budget
nytimes_articles.abstract: House and Senate negotiators struggled for six hours today but failed to agree on how much money to give to a Pentagon that had not asked for it..   The House Defense Appropriations Subcommittee began pushing $1.2 billion last month on a Defense Department that was shyly silent, and today the panel's chairman, Representative John P. Murtha, Democrat of Pennsylvania, walked out of the public session of the House-Senate conference muttering, "We're not budging.'

nytimes_articles.headline: In America; Send Them Back?
nytimes_articles.abstract: The two boys were exhausted, hungry and frightened when they stepped off the plane in Los Angeles in July 1990.   Ferooz Omaid was 17 and his brother, Shikeb, was 15. They spoke little English and had no papers. Within minutes of their arrival at Los Angeles International Airport they were in the hands of immigration authorities.

nytimes_articles.headline: Judge Bars Storage of Spent Nuclear Fuel
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a ruling that the Government says could disrupt the Navy's nuclear-powered fleet, a Federal judge has barred the Energy Department from accepting any more spent nuclear fuel for storage at its atomic reservation in Idaho until the department completes a thorough environmental study of the area.    The order, issued late Monday by Judge Harold L. Ryan of Federal District Court in Boise, involves the 890-square-mile Idaho National Engineering Laboratory, site of the nation's only long-term storage depot for spent naval nuclear fuel.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEWS SUMMARY
nytimes_articles.abstract: International A2-9  U.S. PUTS A-TESTS ON HOLD  President Clinton has decided that the U.S. will follow a "no first test" policy on nuclear arms. Planned tests in the Nevada desert will be put on hold indefinitely, so long as no other tests nuclear arms.  A1  INVESTMENT SCAM IN CHINA  Thousands of Chinese investors have been swindled by a small-time businessman who raised $175 million and then squandered much of the money on luxuries for himself.  A1

nytimes_articles.headline: A Dinosaur Ruling
nytimes_articles.abstract: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor is leading her colleagues -- and the nation -- toward Jurassic Park jurisprudence. The dinosaur of segregated politics has been buried for less than three decades in the South. Now with her disingenuous and ahistorical attack on the Voting Rights Act in a North Carolina case, Justice O'Connor proposes to clone that dinosaur into a monster that could gobble up the nation's hard-won progress toward higher majority membership in Congress, legislatures and local governments.   The case seems a trivial one. Its immediate object is two goofily shaped districts with bare black majorities. Due to these majorities, North Carolina's 12-person House delegation now has two black members -- the first of their race elected from North Carolina since Reconstruction. Previous Supreme Courts would have scoffed at the claim that this minuscule black representation amounted to discrimination against whites.

nytimes_articles.headline: Stein Pulls Out of Advocate Race, Saying His Political Career Is Over
nytimes_articles.abstract: One month after he abandoned his sputtering New York mayoral campaign, City Council President Andrew J. Stein just as abruptly withdrew yesterday as a candidate for re-election to his current job, which is being renamed Public Advocate. He said he might resign before his term expires in December and would never again seek elective office.   "I'm getting out of politics," Mr. Stein said in an interview. "You have to be gung-ho, you have to have complete enthusiasm for it. I've had that for 25 years. It's all I've done since I was 22. I think I've made a difference. But I'm 48 and it's really time to move on."

nytimes_articles.headline: In Tour de France, Target Is Clear but Who Dares Attack?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Claudio Chiappucci, who has twice finished second in the Tour de France, knows how to beat Miguel Indurain. So does Frdric Moncassin, who has never come closer to the Tour than watching it on television. ."The way is to attack him, att

nytimes_articles.headline: Former U. of Miami Aide Indicted
nytimes_articles.abstract: TONY RUSSELL, a former University of Miami academic counselor, was indicted yesterday in Miami on one count of Federal financial aid fraud, capping a two-year investigation into financial aid fraud among Miami athletes. According to the indictment, more than $220,000 in Pell Grant funds were obtained fraudulently between June 1989 and June 1991 and 356 documents were falsified by 91 present or former Miami students, all but several of them athletes.   Russell, who has acknowledged illegally securing up to $2,400 a year per athlete in Pell Grant funds in exchange for a payment of up to $100 each, has accepted a plea bargain arrangement stipulating that he plead guilty. He faces a maximum of five years in prison, up to $440,000 in fines and may be ordered to pay restitution.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Jet Patrolling Iraq Fires Missile at Artillery Site
nytimes_articles.abstract: Three days after an American military strike against Baghdad, a United States warplane fired a missile at an Iraqi antiaircraft artillery site today as Iraq continued to interfere with American patrols and defy United Nations sanctions, Administration officials said.   President Clinton sought to play down the significance of the incident, which came after the American aircraft was targeted by Iraqi radar as it patrolled the no-flight zone declared by the United Nations over southern Iraq.

nytimes_articles.headline: Where Will Five Stars Forward Their Mail?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Five of the country's top college players sat in a hotel conference room today, nervously contemplating their fate in Wednesday night's National Basketball Association draft.   "Wouldn't you be nervous?" asked Jamal Mashburn, the University of Kentucky star who is expected to be among the top four picks. "You could end up on one coast, or another. You don't know what's going to happen, until it happens."

nytimes_articles.headline: Habyan Isn't Expecting a Late Call
nytimes_articles.abstract: A bad week. That is what John Habyan called his treacherous trips to the pitcher's mound during the latest Yankee road trip, when he threw too many sliders, surrendered too many damaging hits and saw his role in the bullpen diminish rapidly as a result. A real bad week.   Actually, Habyan merely endured three suspect outings, but they came at inopportune times and the reliever conceded yesterday that he does not expect to be summoned in the late innings any time soon. In the last two days, Habyan has met with Manager Buck Showalter and General Manager Gene Michael, and they have not been exchanging their favorite recipes.

nytimes_articles.headline: Better, Read the World Trade Rules
nytimes_articles.abstract: The old ghost of Nipponophobia has returned. Roy Denman's opinion column "Now Read the Rules to Japan" (June 17) is full of distortions, clichs and inflammatory statements..Mr. Denman, former director general of external relations of th

nytimes_articles.headline: Albany's Last Chance on Ethics
nytimes_articles.abstract: This has not been a banner year for New Yorkers who had hoped that their Legislature would reduce the influence of vested interests in state and local politics and encourage fairer and more competitive elections. Albany can gain some measure of redemption in the time remaining, but that time is swiftly running out.    The session actually began on a hopeful note. In what is becoming a yearly ritual, the Democratic-run Assembly passed a solid reform package establishing a sensible system of public campaign financing for statewide and legislative races and for easing the state's onerous ballot access rules.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Music; Slyness Opens Concerts In Parks
nytimes_articles.abstract: The speeches by dignitaries and politicians that traditionally precede outdoor concerts can be soporific. But a listener who reflexively tuned them out at the New York Philharmonic's concert on the Great Lawn of Central Park on Monday evening would have missed an uncharacteristic touch of mischievousness. In remarks destined for a place in "The Annals of Especially Sly Buzzword Usage," Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, described the Philharmonic's Mozart, Rossini and Mussorgsky program as "multicultural."   Radical multiculturalists may take umbrage at her use of their concept to describe a collection of works by dead white, European males. But strictly speaking, she was quite right. Huge chasms separate the cultural and musical sensibilities of these three composers, and although outdoor concerts do not normally lend themselves to the examination of such notions, Samuel Wong led the Philharmonic in performances that made a point of the program's stylistic diversity.

nytimes_articles.headline: RESULTS PLUS
nytimes_articles.abstract: BOXING  Duran Gets a Workout and the Decision  Roberto Duran came out with a victory last night, but he was taken the distance and got a solid workout in a 10-round decision over the Canadian Jacques LeBlanc in Bay St. Louis, Miss. The 42-year-old former champion did what he had to do to as he tries to line up a shot at a fifth title, winning a unanimous decision over the former Canadian champion in a supermiddleweight bout. Duran (89-9) was still punching strongly in the final rounds despite an injured right hand he suffered in the fourth round. LeBlanc (22-5-2), 29, lived up to his billing as a brawler, fighting strongly into the final minute despite a bloody nose and cut under the left eye. All five of his professional losses are by decision. The victory puts Duran in position to fight the two-time world champion Vinny Pazienza in October. A victory there could put Duran in line for another title shot. (AP) BASEBALL  U.S. Team Romps Over France  Dante Powell, Todd Helton and Russ Johnson each drove in two runs in an eight-run second inning as the United States rolled to a 16-1 victory over France in the Intercontinental Baseball Cup yesterday in Reggio Emilia, Italy. The game was stopped after six and a half innings because of the international 10-run rule. The victory improves the United States to 4-2 in the round-robin tournament with three games remaining. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Film: The Firm; A Mole in the Den of Corrupt Legal Lions
nytimes_articles.abstract: New lawyer, enigmatic Memphis outfit, via Grisham. Able but slow, with absurd wrap-up.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dancers of 6 Countries Win Prizes but No Gold In Ballet Competition
nytimes_articles.abstract: Seven dancers from six countries received awards on Monday night when the fourth New York International Ballet Competition concluded with a gala at Alice Tully Hall.    The gala, for which Hillary Rodham Clinton served as honorary chairwoman, had Ann Reinking as its host and began with all the competition's dancers, judges and teachers assembled on stage. Each was individually introduced, and the audience gave a special burst of applause to Maya Plisetskaya, the ballerina of the Bolshoi Ballet who served as one of the judges. Gesturing toward the entire group, the competition's executive director, Ilona Copen, exclaimed, "Isn't our family beautiful?"  Solos and Pas de Deux    The performance that followed, by award winners and other competition participants, made it easy to answer that question affirmatively. On the other hand, the fact that some of the dancers seemed lacking in stage experience and stylistic refinement made it understandable why no Gold Medals were presented this year.

nytimes_articles.headline: INSIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Murdoch Wins WaiverTo Acquire The Post   The Federal Communications Commission voted 2-1 to allow Rupert Murdoch to acquire The New York Post, a day before his agreement with a bankruptcy court to operate The Post was to expire. A waiver was needed because he owns a television station in the same market. Page B1. nytimes_articles.headline: U.S Indicts 31 for Extortion Plots In Minority Hiring in Construction
nytimes_articles.abstract: Thirty-one people were indicted yesterday on charges of running eight groups that violently extorted thousands of dollars from New York building contractors under the guise of obtaining construction jobs for black and Hispanic workers.   Federal attorneys in Brooklyn said 22 of the 31 indicted were arrested by F.B.I. agents and the police in raids that started yesterday. Two others are reported to be in prison on other charges and seven have not been found.

nytimes_articles.headline: Republican Draws Fire As Too Soft on Clinton
nytimes_articles.abstract: Anger among Republicans who believe that their leader on the Senate Judiciary Committee has been too easy on Clinton Administration nominees burst into the open today. As a result, the President's choice for a top Justice Department post was put on hold.   The nominee, Eleanor Dean Acheson, a granddaughter of President Harry S. Truman's Secretary of State, Dean Acheson, breezed through a confirmation hearing last week. She had already received the warm endorsement of Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, the committee's ranking Republican, to head the office that recommends judicial appointments and helps set overall policy for the department.

nytimes_articles.headline: On This Tour, Streets Are Paved With Stars
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dear Diary,  SAW van with sign saying, "Stardom Tours, See Hollywood in Manhattan." Wondered, what does that mean? Thought, why not? Called to book a seat.   Welcomed aboard by Michael Dzakulin, the 44-year-old driver and guide, originally from Belgrade. Fellow sightseers were a woman from Sydney and a German surgeon traveling with his 18-year old son.

nytimes_articles.headline: METROPOLITAN GOLF REPORT
nytimes_articles.abstract: M.G.A. Metlife Ike Championship    George Zahringer 3d proved again yesterday that even at the age of 40 he is still a force in amateur golf in the metropolitan area. Zahringer captured the 39th edition of the Ike, the stroke-play championship of the Metropolitan Golf Association, for his 27th tournament triumph.

nytimes_articles.headline: METRO DIGEST
nytimes_articles.abstract: METRO DIGEST  NEW YORK CITY  HOW ABOUT THOSE MIDTOWN BOMBERS?   Forging a fallback position in case efforts to keep the New York Yankees in the Bronx fail, Governor Cuomo has fixed his eyes on a 30-acre railyard on the western edge of midtown Manhattan as a possible way to keep the team from leaving New York City altogether. nytimes_articles.headline: Marathon to Offer Bonuses
nytimes_articles.abstract: An American man or woman finishing first in this year's New York City Marathon could earn as much as $140,000 in prize money plus a new Mercedes-Benz. The bonus prizes were announced yesterday by the New York Road Runners Club, organizers of the Nov. 14 race.   Under the plan, any United States citizen finishing in the top five will earn double the existing prize money awarded while winning would carry a further $100,000. For example, the men's or women's winner receives $20,000 plus the car; so an American winner would get $40,000 -- plus a $100,000 bonus.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Lost Life Remembered
nytimes_articles.abstract: Family and friends of Jenny Soto -- the 23-year-old woman identified as a possible victim of Joel Rifkin -- insisted last night that Ms. Soto was not a prostitute, although some of her friends were.   "We knew she had friends who were prostitutes, but her family took care of her, she would never be a prostitute," said Cynthia Vega, 20, a cousin.

nytimes_articles.headline: Prostitutes on Allen Street Remember Suspect From L.I.
nytimes_articles.abstract: The women who work as prostitutes along a park-like strip of Allen Street said yesterday that they recognized police photographs of Joel Rifkin and remembered him as a man who frequented the Lower East Side looking for sex.    "He used to constantly ask me out on dates, but I told him I didn't go out with strangers," said a tall, skinny woman of 30 in a short black jumpsuit.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: You don't have to be a reigning monarch to have public family squabbles. In France, the COUNT OF PARIS, 85, whose full name is Henri Robert Ferdinand Marie Louis-Philippe d'Orleans and who is one of the two pretenders to the throne of France, is enmeshed in a lawsuit with five of his nine living children over silver, jewelry, art, furnishings and books. The children have gone to court to stop him from selling the contents of Quinta da Anjino, a former family home near Sintra, Portugal.    The Count, his wife, Princess Isabelle d'Orleans-Bragance, and their children lived there in exile from 1945 to 1950, when it again became legal for descendants of former French kings to set foot on French soil. The family kept the house as a vacation retreat, but then sold it a few years ago. The contents, which Sotheby's is planning to auction in Monaco on Saturday and Sunday, are worth an estimated $3.6 million.

nytimes_articles.headline: Police Locate 2 More Bodies Buries on L.I.
nytimes_articles.abstract: Beginning what they called "a long and extensive investigation" into a Long Island man's claims that he killed 17 prostitutes, law-enforcement officials found the bodies of two women today.    As state and local authorities, using dogs and helicopters, fanned out through the region, one body was found near Kennedy International Airport and the other near a county highway in the Hamptons.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dinkins Asserts He Is Better Racial Healer
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sounding what promises to be a central theme of his re-election campaign with unusual bluntness, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he had a special understanding of New York City's racial and ethnic diversity and an ability to bridge it -- and strongly suggested that his opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani, did not.   "On one thing there should be no doubt: the future of our city depends upon our ability to live together and work together, to realize that our great diversity of backgrounds, opinions and perspectives is our greatest gift," Mr. Dinkins said in a luncheon speech to the City Club of New York in Manhattan.
